editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for A. Crook at the Green Dragon in Saint Pauls Church-yard, and for H. Brome at the Gunn in Ivy-Lane,

notesStmt.note: 'The English moor' (E.1782[1]) and 'The love-sick court'(E.1782[2]) have separate title pages, continuous pagination and register, and a final leaf of epilogue. 'Covent Garden weeded' (E.1782[3]) and 'The nevv academy' (E.1782[4]) have separate title pages, continous register, separate pagination, and a final leaf of advertisements. 'Covent garden weeded' has t.p. which reads: 'The weeding of the Covent-Garden'. 'The queen and concubine' (E.1782[5]) has its own t.p., continous pagination and register, and a final leaf of advertisements.

Annotations on Thomason copies: (E.1782[1]; general titlepage): "Jan"; the '9' in the imprint has been crossed out and replaced with an "8"; (E. 1782[3]: "Jan: January"; (E. 1782[5]): "Jan"; the '9' in the imprint has been crossed out and replaced with an "8".
Reproductions of the originals in the British Library.

div.p: The new academy, or, the new exchange.
London, printed or Andrew Crook, at the green dragon in saint Paul's Church-yard: and Henry Brome at the gun in ivy-lane. 1658.

list.head: The actors names.
list.item: Sir Swithin Whimlby, a melancholy widower. Suitor to the lady nestlecock.
Old Matchil, a merchant that married his maid. Gabrialla's guardian.
Young Matchil his son.
Old Lafoy a French gentleman, guardian to young Matchil.
Young F. Lafoy his son.
Mr. Hardyman, captain Valentine's father-in-law. Hannah's father.
Strigood, half brother to Matchil.
Valentine Askal, son-in-law to Hardiman. Hannah's half-brother.
Erasmus a young gentleman, his companion and friend.
Cash, Matchil's prentice.
Nehemiah nestlecock, a foolish gentleman, the lady's son.
Ephraim, the lady nestlecocks servant.
Rafe chameleon an uxorious citizen.
A footpost.

list.head: Women.
list.item: Lady nestlecock, a fond mother.
Mrs. blithe Tripshort, sir Swithin Whimlby's niece.
Hannah, chameleons wife, captain Hardiman's daughter.
Maudlin, Matchil's maid and wife.

div.head: The new academy, or, the new exchange.
Act. i.
div.p: Is this the entertainment you promised me in the jovial merchant's house? Is this the great interest you have in his huge hospitality? when by half an hour's attendance and entreats, we cannot obtain the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: I wonder at it; sure some strange disaster has suddenly befallen him. He was, last night the merriest man alive, drank healths; told tales; sung catches; troll the bowl; toss the canikin; and what not! and all for joy, that his son, he said, was upon his return, whom he has not seen these dozen years, since he sent him a little lad into France, to be bred there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I heard he did so; and that in lieu, by way of
exchange, he brings up the daughter of the Parisien that breeds his son.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But is that daughter so exquisite a creature, as is this merchant Matchills own whom you so much extol?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: They are both so equally handsome, and virtuous, that, be their dowries so, and their consents alike, I'll take my choice of cross and pile for either, with such a friend as thou art.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Troth, and that's friendly spoken, Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: It is so Val. yet not with some policy do I wish thee a fortune: for, insooth. young gentleman, though I like your person, and some of your qualities, yet by reason of your wants, I find you something heavy on my purse-strings; and myself scarce able to supply you. And, if we fail of good matches, I must even turn you over shortly to the hopes you host of in your city-mystresses and tradesmen's wives —.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace, prithee hold thy peace.
Friend Cash! Is your master, Mr. Matchill yet at leisure 〈◊〉 be seen?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: He much desires, sir, to be held excused. 'tis true that he invited you. His dinner's ready; and his heart welcomes you. But he has met with an unhappy news today. —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I feared some ill. What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: His only son, whom he of late expected home out of France, we hear, is dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: His daughter will prove a bouncing match then.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: That's the impression the heavy news makes in you, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen, although my masters sudden sadness shuts him from you. His meat and wine are ready. There are some good company in his parlour too, pray stay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are his fair daughter, and the french-born
Damsel there to be seen?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Both. Pray be pleased to enter.
I hope his passionate fit ere you have dined will be passed over. He is not wont to suffer long under the hand of sorrow.
sp.l: 'Tis like that you shall see him ere you go.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: In that fair hope we'll enter and fall to.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: 'Tis like you shall fall short though of your aim
At my young mistress, who by this black news,
Becomes my master's heir, and so the white
That all the gallant suitors of the city
And court will level their keen shafts at. Where
Are mine own hopes then, that stood as fair
In competition for her, love as any,
When the great noise of her inheritance,
Shall drown each lover's tongue, that cannot say,
It is a lord's at least, I rather wish
The young man had not did.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where's my Boykin? my Friskoe? my delight? my cash? by what better name can I call thee?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: O me! Master Strigood, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I come to comfort my brother in his sorrow.
His son is dead, they say. Ha! is't not so?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And he is almost dead with sorrow: back sir.
The sight of you, that are his sole vexation, will make him mad.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That is my way to cure him.
Madness drowns grief in any man. — probatum.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Good Mr. Strigood depart.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Good Mr. cash, and Mr. matchils man.
I'll see your master. What! deny his brother?
His noun natural brother? By the surer side too
We tumbled in one pannier; though we had
Two rippiers, sweet sir, I am the elder too
Strigood was in my mother before Matchill
Therefore, because I have spent an estate
And he has got-one, must not I maintain
Myself the better man?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Yes: if you had the wherewithal.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, you had been as good ha' held your tongue.
Lend me some money Cash.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I have no money, sir, but what's my masters.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Whose money, sir, was that you played last night.
Among the knights and braveries at the ordinary?
Gold by the handfuls, Cash! Lend me two pieces.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Speak lower, sir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me three pieces, Cash.
Before I speak too loud, whose money's that
You use to wear abroad at feasts and revels
In silver lace and satin; though you wait
At home in simple serge, or broadcloth, sir.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Be not so loud, I pray.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me five pieces.
I shall grow louder else. Who pays your barber?
I mean not for your prentice pig-haired cut
Your wear at home here; but your periwigs;
Your locks and lady-ware that dangle in 'em,
Like straws in the bush natural of a bedlam?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: What mean you Mr. Strygood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I mean ten pieces now; I'll go no less. Do not I know your haunts? —

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You may; you trained one to 'em

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Do not I know your our leaps, and vagaries?
Your tiring houses, where you shift yourself,
Your privy lodgings, for your trunks and punks?
Your midnight walks and meetings? Come, the money.
And, hark thee, though thou modest my brother by't.
I'll keep thy council: thou shalt find me virtuous.
I want, he gives me nothing; and thou canst not
Do him better service, then relieve his brother.

sp.speaker: Cash:
sp.l: I am in; and must, to hide my old faults, do
Like an ill painter, daub 'em o'er with new.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Quickly. I shall grow loud again else Cash.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Sir, I am in your hands, here are ten pieces.
I hope you will not think my master for ▪ ●●.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: No; no for all he has that comes through thy hands.
My nimble cash; and from his I am sure,
Though I were starving, I should finger nothing.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Will you go now?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I'll see him ere I go,
And dine, if there be meat i'th' house. What eats
Are there within I'll draw a knife among 'em.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: This desperate old Russian, would undo me,
But he hopes to waste his brother by me.
He has spent himself to beggary; and would fall so,
But that he has pernicious fire in's brain,
that raging spreads to ruin others with him.
I must beware of him,
Is she come too?
Then 'tis decreed, my master must, from sorrow, suffer in madness.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go home Ephraim.
And have a care you suffer not my boy
To straggle forth among his unhappy play-mates,
For fear of mischief.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: It shall be my care.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What do you lock up my brother, ha? —

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: He has locked himself up, madam; and will suffer
None to come at him, till his sorrowful fit
Be somewhat over.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Not's own sister, ha? —

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Nor his half brother neither: yet he's here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is he here, ha? That Strygood? Is he here?
Hang him old reprobate. And beshrew thy heart,
For a young varlet, to call him our brother.
It is no marvel, if my brother Matchil
Lock up himself, and such a wickedness
Be in his house, as is that Strygood, ha —
Let him take heed, he comes not in my nail reach,
And call me sister, or my brother, brother,
Like a debauched old villain, as he is.
O that my husband nestlecock were alive,
But for three minutes, to send him to
Newgate, if he presume to call me sister
But I command you in my husband's name,
Who was a justice, when he lived, to thrust him
Out of your master's doors, my brother's house.
Lest I be sick with the loathed sight of him.
You will not disobey this, will you, ha? —
If not, why stir you not? ha. —

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I must remove
This fit of hers. There's but one way to do it;
And that's to talk of her white boy, she's fond on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you not send him packing, ha? —

sp.speaker: Cash,
sp.l: First, madam.
(By your good ladyship's leave) how does your son
Sweet master Nehemiah nestlecock?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you courteous friend. In truth, last night,
One of my coach-geldings fell lame, and I,
By that constrained to come afoot,
Was forced to leave my boy at home; or else
He had come with me, to have been a comfort
To his sad uncle: but I would not now
For twice my gelding's price, my child were here;
And that foul fiend i'th' house, whose very looks
Would fright him into sickness.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: O good lady!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I can't so soon forget the fright he took
At seeing the roguish juggler once eat tow,
And blow it out of's mouth in fire and smoke,
He lay a fortnight by't.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: That's two years since.
And he was then but young, he's now a man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alack a child; but going in's nineteenth year.
Where's my niece Joyce?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Within there madam; so is Gabriella
The French young gentlewoman to attend you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll stay with them till I may see my brother.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I hope old Strygood, who now on the sudden
Hath slipped her memory, meets her by the ears first.
sp.stage: Enter Matchil, an opeu letter in his hands.
sp.l: But the good minute's come, before I looked for't.
My master now appears. He looks most sourly
Expressing more of anger then of grief.
I fear, old Strygood was so loud with me,
That he hath overheard us, and I shall break
Before I am a freeman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sorrow be gone
And puling grief away, whilst I take in
A nobler and more manly passion;
Anger, that may instruct me to revenge.
My child is lost by treacherous neglect
In that false Frenchman, to whose seeming care
I trusted the chief comfort of my life;
My boy. Nay, read again. 'tis written, here,
He was grown man:

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: His man, I think, he said.
sp.stage: Cash listens to Matchil, and speaks aside.
sp.l: Does your man trouble you. I do not like that

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And here he writes that in his youthful spring
And heat of spirit, he began to grow
Intemperate and wild —

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Wild! Are you there?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Which drew him on to riotous expense —

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And there again, to riotous expense!
'Tis I directly that he's troubled with.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And sometimes into quarrels. What of that?
In all this he was still mine own. O boy —

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Some slave has writ some fearful information.
Against me, and he hugs and kisses it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And had his guardian had a feeling care
(Hang his French friendship) over my dear child,
as I had over his, these youthful follies
Might have been tempered into manly virtues.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I hear not that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I fall back again
From my revenge to grief. Away; I will not.
Here's the death-doing point. These slight disorders.
In my young forward son (I find it here)
Were, by his churlish and perfidious guardian,
Interpreted no less than reprobation,
And, by his ignorant cruelty, so punished.
For, here he shuts his ear and door against him:
When suddenly the loose licentious world
Soothes on his youthful, in judicious courage
To imminent destruction; so being engaged
In a rash quarrel, he in duel fell.
Th' opponents sword was instrument; yet I infer.
Lafoy, his guardian was his murderer.
Farewell, my boy; and this is the last tear
Thou shalt wring from me. Something I'll do,
Shall show a father's love, and valour too.
I'm young enough to draw a sword in France, yet.
But first — come hither, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Now it comes.

sp.speaker: Mrt.
sp.l: I purpose straight to order my estate
Look that you forthwith perfect my accounts;
And bring me all my books of debtor and creditor,
Receipts and payments, what you have in wares,
And what in cash, let me inform myself.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: 'Tis as I feared.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll set all right and straight,
All statutes, bonds, bills, and sealed instruments
That do concern me, I have in my closet
Or at my counsels, or my scriveners.
I'll call in them myself. Why dost thou look so amazedly?
Wouldst have me yield a reason? why, I'll tell thee
I mean to make a voyage; and, perhaps,
To settle and proportion out my estate
By will, before I go. Do you as I command you.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Whatever he pretends, I know his drift:
And, ere I'll be discovered by my stay;
Being run out, I'll choose to run away. —

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My daughter in the first place must be cared for.
I'll make her a good match. My next in blood then,
My knave-half-brother, and my whole fool-sister.
But the best is, her ladyship has enough;
And all I have, in Strygood's hands, were nothing.
Therefore I'll purpose nothing to him. Oh.
The joy and torment of my life, at once
Appear to me. I must divide them, thus.
Hence hated issue of my mortal foe
Whom I have fostered with a parent's piety
As carefully and dear as mine own.
While the inhumane cruelty of thy sire
Has to untimely death exposed my son.
Thank me I kill not thee; so leave my house.
There's French enough in town, that may befriend you.
To pack you o'er to Paris; what's your own
Take w'ye, and go. Why cleave you to her so?
Forsake her, cast her off. Are not my words
Of force, but I must use my hands to part ye?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Dear, honoured father, I beseech you hear me.
In parting us you separate life from me,
and therein act a real cruelty
On me your only child, sharper than that,
Which you can but pretend done by her father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Dared thou speak so?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I cannot live from her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O monstrous. Pray, your reason. Why not live?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You know, sir, from our infancy we have been,
Bred up together, by your tender care
As we had been twin-born, and equally
Your own; and by a selfsame education,
We have grown hitherto, in one affection,
We are both but one body, and one mind,
What Gabriella was, I was, what I, was she.
And, till this hapless hour, you have enjoined me,
Nay, charged me on your blessing, not to arrogate
More of your love unto myself, then her,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That was, 'cause I presumed her father loved,
Or should have loved my son, your brother.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I never knew brother, or sister, I;
Nor my poor self, but in my Gabrella.
Then blame me not to love her, I beseech you
— upon me knees.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Th' art knee-deep in rebellion.
Unnatural Gipsy, since thou provest my torment
In being the same with her; and hast declared
Thyself no more my child, than she, whom now
I do abhor, avoid, with her, my sight.
Rise, and be gone, lest thou pull curses on thee
Shall sink thee into earth.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: O rather, sir.
Let me, 'gainst whom your fury first was bent
Suffer alone the sharpness of your vengeance:
And let it not be said,'cause you surmise,
My father lost your son, that, therefore, you
have cast away your daughter. Hurl me, rather,
Into the ruthless waves to seek my way;
Or do but take her, hold her in the arms
Of your paternal love, and I'll take flight
To wean her to you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: She cannot, may not leave me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Out of my doors then, with her. —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What's the matter? ha —

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Such as you cannot mend, dear lady sister.
What come you hither with your ha — for? Ha —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To comfort you, dear brother, if you'll hear me.
Your son is dead, they say; and here I find
Your daughter is rebellious 'gainst; our will.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You speak much comfort, do you not, think you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But is it so Joyce? ha! — I thought you, Joyce,
Would have rejoiced your father in obedience, Joyce;
And not afflict him with your stubbornness.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O this impertinent woman!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But my brother,
Let me advise you, rather than suffer her
To be an eyesore to you, put her out,
Where she may learn more duty. If you please
I'll take her home, and show her how it should be

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes, as you have shown your nestlecock, your son.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ay, there's a child! Brother, you'll pardon me,
If I aspire in hope, that he shall be
your heir, if Joyce miscarry in rebellion.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And therefore you would breed her. How the devil
Works in a covetous woman! Though a fool too.
Your son's an ass; an idiot; and yourself
No better, that have bred him so. Do you tell me
Of your sweet sugar-chopped nestle coxcomb?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha —

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He's fit to inherit nothing but a place
I'th' spittle-house, fool's college, yond, at Knightsbridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And did I come to bring thee consolation?
Now let me tell thee, I rejoice in thy
Just punishment, thy scourge of crosses. Thou,
That for these six years space ▪ until this day,
Hast kept continual feast and jollity
For thy wife's death, who was too good for thee.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Right, for she was my master, a perpetual
Vexation to me, while she was aboveground
Your ladyship could not have spoke more comfort to me
Then the remembrance of that shook-off shackle,
Which now, in my affliction makes me smile,
And were I on her grave, I could cut capers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A further punishment, I prophecy
Grows in the neck of thy lewd insolence

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I could e'en find in heart to marry again,
In spite, now, of thy witchcraft, my son dead!
My daughter disobedient! and your child
A very chilblain. What have I to do
But marry again: all women are not devils,
I may yet get an heir unto my mind.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Art thou here too —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stay, you forget your brother, Mr. Matchil.
You have matched ill once already; and take heed
You match not worse, your children, though untoward.
And taking of the devilish shrew, their mother,
Were likely of your own begetting; yet
Your second wife may bring you a supply
Of heirs, but who must get them, first is doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thy impudence amazes me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'm sick at sight of the lewd reprobate.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: D'ye cast about for heirs; and have besides
Your daughter here, a brother and a sister?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Call not thyself our brother. He appears
U●●●nde to me, but thou insufferable,
I loathe to look upon thee.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He has spoke
sp.p: Against her aunt, her mooncalf son. I'll make her love me best, and presently.
sp.l: Brother, I say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot look upon thee.
Provoke me not to ●●eech, I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Give me leave to speak; hold you your peace;
Hear but my brotherly advice; and when
Give your consent in silence.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: Hum hum, etc.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hear him not.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: Nor you neither, hum — hum — hum.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am not angry with you now; and therefore
I charge you, hear him not.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: Hum hum —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: My advice is thus, that for your daughter's good.
For mine own good, and for your sister's good.
And for her son, your nephew's good.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How's that? ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And chiefly for your own good, and the credit
A wise man would desire to hold i'th' world,
Think not of marrying, nor of buying horns
At the whole value of your whole estate,
But match your daughter while you have the means
In your own hands; give her a good round portion,
Here are deserving gentlemen i'th' house.
Next, think of me your brother, that has spent
In downright fellowship (Heaven knows what
All fraudulent purposes to make any man
A miser or a gainer by't) a fair estate.
And now do want a brotherly supply.
A hundred a year or so: but above all
Fasten your land unto your sister's son.
That hopeful gentleman, sweet Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: (Mat)
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now brother you may hear him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: What though it straggle from the name of Matchil.
Remember yet he is your mother's grandchild.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why d'ye not hear him, brother? —

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As I hope
To be a landed man myself,
Had I a thousand yearly, I would leave't him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Truly, I thank you. Now I'll call you brother.
You're a good natured gentleman if you had it.
Come home, and see my son. — will you not hear him? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I need not, nor yourself. I see you gape
Like monsters that would swallow me alive.
I know your minds; and I will do mine own.
And, thus it is. Stay, let me stay a little.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Look you how wild he looks.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He's falling mad.
Stark staring mad,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would he had a wife then,
For nothing else can tame him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So it shall be.
First, I'll be master of mine own estate.
Next —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Take a wife to master that, and you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Next, you mademoiselle, (On whom with patience
I cannot look) forsake my house, and suddenly;
Linger not for a man to wait upon you,
But let your black bag guard you, 'tis a fashion
Begun amongst us here by your own nation.
And if I longer must call you my daughter,
Forsake you her.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: What mine own heart? dear sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: At your own choice. I can force her departure,
Though not persuade your stay, determine quickly
Either to leave her, and enjoy a father,
Or never more expect a father's blessing.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Dear, mine own heart, leave me, obey your father.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: It must be to my death then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll be sudden.
Therefore be you as brief in your resolve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, poor hearts. Just so loath
To part was I and my son Nehemiah
Today when I came forth.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Niece Joyce, let me
Advise you. —

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray, sir, none of your advices.
Let her advise herself; whilst I impart
To you my next intention; which is thus.
To end your strife for shares in mine estate
I'll venture on a wife: indeed I'll marry

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you so? ha!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes indeed la, —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: If then
You'll estate nothing on me for my life
Give me a see to help you to a wife,
I can, a good one.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll none, sir, of your good ones.
Besides, sir, I'm provided.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are not, are you? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let it suffice, I say't, so quit my house.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Shall I expect then nothing?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray sir, do.
'Tis all I can afford you. You have wit,
Yes, you can dance, tread money out of rushes,
Slight and activity to live upon.
A nimble brain, quick hands and airy heels
To get a living.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray fall to practice.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I may, sir, to your cost, if you put off
Your daughter with her sweetheart, her mon coeur
There, as she calls her. Dear, my lady sister;
You see how churlishly this merchant uses us.
He has forgotten, sure, he was born a gentleman.
Will you be pleased, I speak to you in your ear.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Any way, brother Strigood, hang him, Nabal,
To warn me out o's house; and not alone,
To turn a stranger from within his gates,
But offer to cast out his child too, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis about that I'd speak, pray madam hark you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Noble Mr. Matchil, though we are your meat
before we saw you you will give us leave
To take our leaves, and thank you ere we part.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We've heard your cause of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I have overpast it. Hark ye gentlemen

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.l: You'll give us leave first to salute the ladies.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, if you love me, hear me first.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Your will, sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Niece, you shall no way disobey your father
In being ruled by me.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, so, it takes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You and your second self shall home with me
Until his furious humour be blown over.
To which the first means is to 〈◊〉 his fight,
And then let me alone to make your peace.

sp.speaker: Joy. Gab.
sp.l: We thank your ladyship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: So let us slip.
Home to my house together.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hist brother, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As glad as ever fox was of his prey

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis even so, gentlemen, sorrow finds no lodging.
In my light heart sometimes she knocks at door,
And takes a drink, but here she must not sit by't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You're happy sir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet I have heard you say
You never tasted joy for divers years
Till your wife died: since when, a King of mirth,
And now to marry again is such a thing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes sir, 'tis such a thing that I will marry
That I fore know can never disobey me
And I'll defy the devil to dishonest her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Is she so ugly?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, he means so virtuous.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-said, sir, you shall drink before me. Rachel, Maudlin.
sp.l: 'Protest you shall though't be in my own house.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now he resumes his humour.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Rachel I say,
Bring me a can of sack.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But how can you
Presume before the dangerous marriage-trial
That she whom you've chosen will be obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do ye think he has not tried her? There's a question

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-said again. I was about to say so.
Rachel, some sack, I say. Yes, I have tried her, sir,
Tried her, and tried her again; all over and over
These five years day and night; and still obedient.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Then you are sure to her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I never used
A marriage-question, not a-wooing word,
But do all by command, she is so obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And yet she's chaste and virtuous withal.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-said again, sir, so I was a saying.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But we have talked away the gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No matter, let 'em go. Would they were far enough.
sp.stage: Enter Rachel, silver can and napkin.
sp.p: Come, the sack, the sack. — who taught you that courtesy maid.
sp.l: Pray try a better to the gentleman.
Protest you shall begin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your own house, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll rather gi' ye my house, then break my word in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: you're lord here, and may command me, sir. And so my service to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll do you reason, sir.
Be ready with your napkin, and a lower duck maid.
I'll hang dead weight at your buttocks else. So.
Is not this obedience, gentlemen, Mr. Erasmus?
Mus, I will call thee Mus, I love to be
Familiar, where I love; and godamercy
For your friend here; you both shall see my daughter.
But my French damosel and I are parted
I hope by this time. So here's to you Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: To me, to me, to me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ha boy, art there? dispatch
Your curtsy quickly, and go call my daughter.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: She is gone forth, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Forth, ha? when? whither?
La ye, she thinks I'm angry, and the finger
Is in the eye already. Is not this
Fear and obedience, gentlemen? who went with her.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: She went with my lady nestlecock, to bring Gabriella on her way they said.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would
They were all in France together.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She comes again, I doubt not. Dry your eyes.
And drink that sack, without a curtsy, drink it.
You do not know my meaning, gentlemen.
Stay: now give me't again. — now go and dry
Your face within — without a curtsy? ha!
Now is not this obedience, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But this is not the rare obedient piece
That you will marry?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You do not hear me say so.
But I presume, as much obedience
In her I have made choice of.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Marry a maid.
And we will be her henchboys, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I'll have no such blades about my wife's haunches.
But come, to end this tedious scene, in which
I ha' passed the purgatory of my passions
Of sorrow, anger, fear, and hope at last.
I am refined, sublimed, exalted, fixed
In my true sphere of mirth; where loves my object.
And bloody thought of black revenge cast by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Could your fair breast harbour a bloody thought?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: For some few minutes, in which ecstasy
I meant to ha' gone, as other gallants do.
To fight in France, forsooth, and charged my man
To draw up his accounts, call in my moneys,
Thought to have made my will —.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I saw your cashier
Go forth e'en now with a strong lusty porter
Loaden with money: I will not say my teeth
Watered at it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But 'twas enough to make
A very true man's fingers itch.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot
Think he is run away; but yet I like not
His carrying forth, when I say, fetch in money.
But this is from my purpose. Love ye mirth?
Let's in, and drink, and talk. That gives it birth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I prithee now, I prithee, prithee now
Urge me no more in this case; for I cannot,
nor I wo' not so I wo' not, I be jealous
Of mine own wife, mine own dear flesh and blood?
That's such a thing! I pidee speak no more on't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You show you love Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So I hope I do Nan.
My cock, my pity nittle nansie cocksy,
Do I not show my love when I deny thee
Unreasonable requests? I never heard
Of woman that desired a loving husband
To be a jealous master over her.
Especially a city-shopkeeper.
The best part of whose trade runs through the hands
Of his fair wife too! 'tis unreasonable.
And thou the sirst that e'er take up the humour.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you the sirst that e'er I knew besotted
Into a wilful confidence, which renders
Me to a vile construction; and yourself
By leaving me to all assaults and hazards
Have got the reputation of a wittol.
Or one that seems contented to become so.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Hon soit qui maly ponse.
My cock, my nansie cock, my cocksy nansie,
Kiss me, and use thine own conscience: I scorn
The yellow sickness, ay, let 'em all say what they will.
D'einty, come thou to me. I will not lose
An hair's breadth of my humour, nor retain
An ill thought of my cock's honesty
For all the wealth i' the exchange, not I

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I not desire you should, but only that
You will not seem so careless of my credit,
Exposing me to all temptations
Of the wild gallantry of the wanton time.
By whom (Although my chastity remains
Untouched) my name and your discretion suffers.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish, honi soit again: cock, I defy
Calumniation and detraction I.
When I am jealous, let the horn-curse take me;
And let me be with hornets stung to death.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Still you fly from the point, I would not have
You vex yourself with causeless jealousy
Over my constant love; but only seem
A little watchful o'er my reputation.
Whereby you may decline men's lewd attempts.
And not to throw me upon opportunities
To draw them on; as if I were a thing
S●● out, as in your shop, for common sale.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, thou shalt never tie me to't: not I.
I must not lose my harmless recreations
Abroad to snook over my wife at home.
Thoughtest ha' me like the hare-brained point-tagger,
That used to hammer his fingers at one end
O'th' shop, while's wife was bargaining at the other?
Not I; sweet cock, pidee let's hear no more on't.
Now friend! Is your business to me or my wife?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: This superscription will inform you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To my dear daughter Mrs. Hannah chameleon, at her shop or house in or near the new exchange.

sp.speaker: Cock
sp.p: Take it quickly, what a knave art thou to put a letter in my hands, that is directed to my wife. Sbobs I would not ha' opened it for forty pound.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: If all husbands in the city were of his mind, it were a forest of fools indeed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I must leave thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Pray stay a little. This letter's from my father.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I hope the good captain's well.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, very well, pray read his letter here.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, you shall pardon me. Not I.
I have a match to play at the duckingpond.
Prithee foreslow not my occasions, cock,
As I forbear to pry into thy secrets.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Here's nothing but what I would have you see.
There's for your postage, friend. It needs no answer.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I thank you, mistress.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But if you will not stay to read this letter.
You shall not deny me one thing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What is it, quickly? my sweet Nanny cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here, take this pen: write here a word or sentence.
What you please. But keep it well in mind,
And look that you be sure to know't again
When I shall show't you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis done, there: I defy, and dare the devil and all his clerks to counterfeit my hand. So, my sweet cock, a kiss and adieu.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well Rafe, remember that you won't be jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, sbobs yonder comes one of the blades,
That thou wouldst have me have an eye to; he
That lives by his wits, and yet is seldom sober:
That goes so gallantly, and has no credit,
Nor ever buys with ready money; but
Barters commodity for commodity.
(Such as it is) with tradesmen's wives, they say.
What call you him, o Askal; there's another
Comes with him too. Into thy shop, good cock.
I wo' not stay, not I. So, farewell cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And farewell coxcomb, some wife would say now.
I am much troubled at his silliness.
And would to right me, strain a woman's wit,
Knew I with modesty how to answer it.
Something I'll do.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Was ever such a humour in a man, as this mad
Merchant Matchil is possessed with.
To marry so, to spite his child and kindred.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has made his daughter by't a match worth nothing.
And there your hope is gone.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And yours in me.
For as I said before, good Valentine.
I must return you to your city wives.
By the old trade to pick your maintenance
Out of 'em, as you boast you can.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well, sir.
And now to let you know that I can live
Without the helps of such cool friends as you.
I'll show you a present probability.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dost see yond pretty mumping piece i'th' shop there?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, is that one —?

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: One o'th' forty, boy,
That renders tribute in to my exchequer.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Didst ever lie with her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How plain you are. Not I, not I.
That's her fool-husband's word.
Let it suffice that I have seen her thrice.
And that I lay with, drink, and wear her money.
O 'tis the sweetest rogue.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: How got you acquainted.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll tell you that, walking by chance as now,
Before her shop, where a young gentleman
Was bargaining, he called me by my name,

sp.speaker: Val Askall.
sp.l: Instantly her eye was fixed,
And straight ran over my delineaments,
Which I set to her view; and took occasion
To ask her how the object pleased her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Boldface.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I never lost by that.
She then demands, is your name Askall, sir?
I answer, yes. Pray of what country, sir?
I told her; when a sudden flaming blush
Did in her face betray the fire of love,
That was at th' instant raging in her breast,
She looked me through and through. Sighed, turned away.
Then looked again under her hat-brims thus.
And thus I nimbly catched her with mine eye.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Ay, thou hast a devilish catch i'that same eye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, what I have, I have. I gave a leer
With that same eye that made her turn her whitesup.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But to the point.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why do you think a woman's so quickly brought to th' point?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What followed then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I saw she was struck, and thus I gave her line
To play withal. I whispered in her ear,
The way to find my lodging and my service.
Next morning early comes a message to me,
Inviting me to dinner: cheer and welcome
Plenteously flowed; and sir, before we parted
Upon some private conference, twenty pieces
Were clutched into this hand, but with a caution
To be discreet and thrifty of her purse,
And keep a friend in store. I have been modest,
And have not struck her since, but for ten more.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And that's your last.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I le hold you ten uh that
See she has spied me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: What lack ye, gentlemen; fair cutwork bands, boot-hose, or boot-hose tops, shirts, waistcoats, nightcaps, what will you buy?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I come not now to buy.
But in plain terms to borrow. Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not on these terms.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sure thou mistakest the woman.
This is not she, thou talkest so freely on Bounce.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She's cautious before thee. Walk off a little.
Now you may hear me, lady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Give me leave
A little, first to wonder at your rashness,
To talk so openly before a stranger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My intimate friend: I'll trust him with my life.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What's that to my unblemished reputation?
'Tis not your life can salve that, being wounded.
But thus it is, when women out of goodness
Hazard their fortunes to relieve the wants
Of such as you, that carry no respect,
But to your own licentious appetites.
And think no favour's sweet, unless you may
Have privilege to boast 'em to our shame.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do not boast of yours.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Pray, boast no more
Than you have found, and much good may they do you.
'Tis not poor thirty pieces can undo me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, nor ten more I hope; and that's the sum
I would entreat: all makes but forty pound.
I'll pay thee like a gentleman, as I am one,
Either in money; or dost hear me, rogue,
In what shall please thee better. Come, be wise,
thy husband's a dull ducking gamester. And
Kennels his water-dog in Turnbull-street.
We'll answer his delights with better sport.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: There's your presumption.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, 'tis my ambition.
When shall we walk to Totnam? or cross o'er
The water, or take coach to Kengington
Or Paddington; or to some one or other
O'th' city outleaps for an afternoon,
And hear the cuckoo sing to th' purpose? when?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.l: A woman were a wise one that would trust
Herself in such wild hands as yours; to have
Her name made tavern-talk among your blade,
And thrust i'th'list of your loose-hilted mistresses:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O no; fie no: you cannot think how close
And careful I will be. Hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cannot blame this fellow now so much
For using of his wits to get his living,
Though in an idle way; as for traducing
People of worth and virtue, as this woman
Who I am credibly informed is virtuous
And too discreet for him to shark upon.
Therefore to grace himself, he slanders her.
I have always liked his company till now,
And shall hereafter be more wary of him.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well sir, upon your faithful protestation,
And vow of secrecy, here's ten pieces more.
You have found a tender-hearted woman of me
Over your wants; and all the satisfaction
That I desire, is, that I may not suffer
Under a lavish tongue; 'tis easy payment.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, but I'll pay thee better. Therefore tell me, when we shall meet and have a spirit abroad.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Your friend stays for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pish, let him stay.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: You slight him now, but he knows all your counsels.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By this good tongue, no more than the unbegotten Hans that I mean to clap into thy Kelder.
sp.l: Nor ever shall: dost think I am so foolish
To talk away my hopes? No, thou art my fairy,
Pinch me to death when I discover thee.

sp.speaker: Han,
sp.l: Go to, avoid suspicion then, besides
I have occasions that do call me hence.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Your stay was somewhat long.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet 'twas to purpose.
As here you may behold, but I must make no words on't.
She has enjoined me that. O 'tis a cunning Gipsy.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So't seems, by trusting thee that hast no power to keep a secret.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, to tell you true.
My conscience will not bear't, I cannot be
So ungrateful to receive a courtesy,
But to acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet thou hast the conscience
To work a man's estate out of his hands
By his wife's frailty, even to break his back.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis rather to be feared she may break mine.
She's a tight strong docked tit.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O tradesmen, why do you marry?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why? to make tradeswomen.
For gentlemen that want money and commodity.
You know the thing that I call father in 〈◊〉,
That had my mother's whole estate, and buried her,
Allows me nothing.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thank your own sweet courses.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My courses are sweet courses, they serve me to live upon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But I shall put you off
o'one of your sweet courses, or at least
I'll strain a point of friendship to be satisfied
Touching this woman, 'twill be worth discovery.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But why these cloudy looks? do not you like my courses? ha ▪

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy, Val.
I was upon our former subject Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I there's a hasty match clapped up. You asked
Why tradesmen marry, there's a marriage now!
A humorous coxcomb that could never laugh
In all his last wives days; and since her death
Could never be sad. For him to marry his malkin
For poor and coarse obedience. Well. I hope
To take my course in his house yet for all.
Her boasted chastity and obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wouldst thou touch such a thing?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, not for money?
She can pay well and her ugliness cannot fright me
I can do that work winking.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She can be no such woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tell not me
What any woman can or cannot be,
You'll give me leave to try my fortune with her,

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, and walk with you towards it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No news, no tidings of 'em, Ephraim, ha!
Was even such a scape?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Not since the rape
Of H●llon● I'm persuaded. I have searched
With narrow eyes (As I may say) with care,
And diligence in most secret places.
And can no way inform myself, what is
Betid of the young damosels, or old squire.
Your niece, and the French virgin, and the man
unworthy to be called your brother Strigood.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O hang him villain.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Doubtless 'twas his plot
To work upon your ladyship's good nature
To harbour them, that he might take th' advantage
Of stealing them away.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What to do, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: To do? much may be done by his seducements,
On two such tender virgins, though he should
But plant them in our suburbs: but my fear
Is that he has transported them beyond seas
Into some nunnery. Your ladyship
Knows he is adverse in religion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know he is of none.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Satan will work.
The stronger in him, then to their subversion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How shall I answer now my brother Matchil?
But he is justly served to marry so.
The thought of it torments me. Where's my comfort?
Where's Nehemiah, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: He's busy, madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What, at his book? or at his music, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: That is, his ballet, or his Jew's trump. No,
Madam. He is busy at his exercise of arms
With a new casting top, a cat and cat-stick,
I bought and brought him home.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you for 'em,
My careful discreet Ephraim. I like
His harmless exercises well.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I hope,
Your ladyship can say since I have had
The government of him under your ladyship,
I have been careful of the gentleman,
And have his love withal so much, that I
Dare say (I hope you'll pardon the comparison)
That had you married me (Which was as likely
as that your brother would have taken his maid.
I think that Mr. Nehemiah would not
Have run away in hatred of our match,
As Mrs. Joyce. it seems, hath done of theirs.
I hope your ladyship's pardon, I understand
My duty.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And you speak but reason Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I have given her there a touch of my affection.
Who knows how it may work?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go call him in.
I would not have him over heat himself.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: 'Tis a good care. And madam, by the way,
Let me advise, that since his riper years
Require, and that fair propositions
Of marriage are tendered for him, that
We gently by degrees, do take him off
From childish exercise, indeed plain boys play.
More manly would become him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You would have him
Do worse then, would you? and be naught, you varlet?
What! would you have him play at mans-game, ha?
Fore he be married, ha! what, what! how now!
Is it but up and ride w'ye, ha!

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I humbly
Beseech your ladyship's pardon, I will call
Sweet Mr. Nehemiah to your worship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go, thou'rt an honest man. I know thou lovest him.
Indeed he's all my comfort and my care
And I must naturally respect all those
That do partake with me my care of him.
sp.stage: Enter Nehemiah, looking down and eating.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: My boy Negh, son Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Forsooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That's my good lamb. Hold up thy head; and thou.
Shalt have a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But mother f sooth, when I have her,
Will she play with me at peg-top?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: At any thing, my boy.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And she ha' not good box and steel, I shall so grull her.
And then at Mumbledepeg I will so firk her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But when you're married, you'll find other pastime.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Whatever I say, I have a meaning though.
But yet, I doubt, I shall not forsake all
My old vagaries in a year or two.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know thy will is good to leave thy wag-tricks.
And I commend your understanding in it.
It shows you man, and ready for a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, forsooth, I think so; I amardla.
For I did beat a boy as high as myself
Yesterday, with one hand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where was thy tother.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: The boy had but one hand forsooth. I used both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well thou'rt too witty to live long, I fear.
But as I was saying, son, I do expect
Sir Swithen Whimtby to bring his niece.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Who forsooth, the crying knight, he that has wept
E'er since his lady died; and mourns in colours;
Speaks nothing but in verse, and gives me ballads;
The old knight Powel, that pronounces what d'ye call 'em?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Odes child and elegies. He has been inspired.
With the infection of poetry,
E'er since his wife's departure: and 'tis thought
nothing can put him out, or cure him of it
But a new wife to kill the furious itch of't,

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But is not his niece too big for me? I would be loath
To be overmatched.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O witty, witty, still.
But when she comes Nehemiah, what'll you say to her?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: I'll give her the time of the day or the night
I warrant her, come at what hour she will.
Why if I eat not all before she come.
(And she must try her, if I don't) I'll ask her
If she can speak with plums in her mouth; and then
I'll offer her a long one and two round ones,
And nod at her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You will not, will you, ha?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, I know both what to say and do
I trust I am not to be taught to woo.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Too witty still, I say, to be long-lived.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But hark you mother forsooth; I am told that you
Bear a month's mind to that sir Whimlby,
And a cross match is talked on betwixt you
And the old knight, and me and his young niece.
O ho — is't so?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is no crafty child.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Let me but see how you will handle him now
And mark how I'll come over her with small jerks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O thou'rt a witty wag. A blessing on it.
sp.stage: Enter Ephraim, ushering Whimlby and Blith.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, sir Swithen Whimlby and his niece,
Mrs. blithe Tripshort.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They are very welcome,
Noble sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Noble Mrs. blithe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sweet knight, you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Welcome, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Still weeping.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: O good madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Still weeping for a husband.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, she puts me on't,
She laughs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Laugh with her then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, so I will, and if you laugh
At me, I'll laugh at you again, so I will.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Are you there with me? I'll be here with you then.
Will you eat any sugar-plums? no, I'll eat 'em for you.
There's ha, ha, ha, ha, for you now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do you note, sir Swithin, what a wag it is.
Walk into the next room Nehemiah. Did you note him?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Madam, to tell you true.
My love to you
Springs from the joy,
I take in your sweet boy
sp.stage: — Eph. and that's the way to win her.
sp.l: I can take no delight
But in his sight,
Nor any pride
Since my dear Grissel died,
In all, I see on earth or find in books,
But that which overcomes me in his looks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O sweet sir Swithen, you have all wooed and won me.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Then all my hopes are frustrate.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My son shall have your niece, and for mine own part.
You loving him so well, of what's in me.
I can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Gentle madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: She offers up herself; now may the proverb
Of proffered service light upon her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay, sir Swithen.
Let me entreat you to leave weeping now.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Madam, I cannot so
Forego my woe.
For while I strive
My solace to revive,
I do but still restore
My grief, before
That did betide
When my dear Grissel did.
And when your ladyship appears in sight.
(Pardon) I cannot choose but cry outright.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, good knight. He weeps pure Helicon.
He has not wherewithal to quench his love,
But his own tears. A wife would cool him better.
Why sir, does sight of me renew your grief?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: O madam, madam, yes;
In you the bliss,
That I do miss,
I find enshrined is.
And till, to ease my pain,
I shall regain
In you the bride,
That in my Grissel died.
So oft as she in you to me appears
My numbers cannot cease to flow in tears.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good sir, collect yourself, and be assured
I am your own, so Neh. may have your niece,
With her full dowry of four thousand pounds.
My personal estate is full as much.
That and myself are yours on the cross marriage,
You making me an answerable jointure.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Is't come so near; I'll cross it, or my star ▪
Drop crosses on my head. O vain, vain woman,
To dote on poetry in an old man.
Lady's may love it in the young and bold,
And when they are sick give galley-pots of gold,
For cordial electuaries to cheer
Their cropsick muses; but to an old and sere
Man that outlives his labours, who can be
So vain to give herself away but she.
I had been sitter for her, and I'll watch
Occasion yet, perhaps, to cross the match,
I can turn poet too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dry now your eyes, and answer me in prose,
Are you content to yield to those conditions
I have propounded, ha!

sp.speaker: Vvhim.
sp.l: I am content.
And now for joy could weep,
Finding my Grissel in your ladyship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I hope the young ones do accord as well.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Protest, I cannot abide you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Nor I you.
Amardla, that I cannot.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: They're agreed.
Madam, it seems they both are of one mind.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: I do not like it. What's the matter Nehemiah?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: She is no wife for me, she has broke my jews-trump; look you here else. And almost broke my head with one of my bounding stones.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bless my boy; she has not, has she, ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And yet after all that, and for all I offered to teach her to shoot in my trunk and my stone-bow, do you think she would play with me at trou, madam? no, nor at any thing else. I'll none of her.
And yet I'll have her too. If she will promise to do as I would have her hereafter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There, do you note him there, sir Swithen?
This child has no childish meaning in't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: No madam, no, I know him inwardly
He is my joy, and she shall be conformable,
Or fare the worse.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: She will, I know she will.
Will you not have my son, sweet Mrs. blithe?

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Sweet madam, what to do? ha, ha, I shall be quickly weary with laughing at him. His fooling will soon be stale and tedious; and then to beat him would be as toilsome to me; and lastly, to be tied to nothing but to cuckold him, is such a common town-trick, that I scorn to follow the fashion.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: Can she talk thus? ha!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A merry harmless girl.
Fear not, good madam, she will come about.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: A thousand mile about rather than meet him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I much desire she would; for now my son
Is set a marrying, I warrant it pure thing
It is in pain, till it be at it: ha!
Pray bring her on, sir Swithen, let him kiss her.
Poor heart, he licks his lips; and look how arseward she is.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Fie blithe, be courteous, blithe.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, — she has spit Amard just in my mouth.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Amard, what's that? if you speak French you wrong me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Gip, Mrs. Tripshort. Is this the manners your mother left you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Speak not you of mothers, madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir ●w●then, will you see my child abused so, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I can but grieve for't, madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: My mother is as good as your mother, so she is, for all she's dead.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ay, well-said Neh.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Yes, it appears in your good breeding
Your fine qualities express her virtues sufficiently.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How dare you housewife talk thus to my son, of me, and before my face too? ha! Sir Swithen, can you think well of me, and suffer this, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Alas, good madam, I am down again I know not what to think of living woman now.

sp.speaker: La ▪
sp.p: Do you bring your niece to abuse me?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I am so drowned in tears, that I cannot see what to say to't.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, Amardla, the more I look on her, the better I like her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sayest so, my boy. Besides, I have a conceit she can outscold you ▪ and that's more than ever woman did, I think forsooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For thee, I do forbear her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: By your leave, my lady nestlecock, I have brought a sister of yours here to salute you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Though unworthy to be of your counsel, or at the ceremony, I heard you were married brother. And by a sister's name you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I thank your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir Swithen Whimlby! and your pretty niece! well met, what affairs have you in hand here? what do you cry for your old wife still or for a new one? But hark, you lady sister, where's my daughter?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now for a tempest. Truly sir, I know not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is she not with you, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No truly, sir.
She's slipped from me with her good uncle Strigood.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That thief has sold her then into some bawdy-house
Was this your project for her education,
To steal my child to make a whore of her?
Are you turned lady bawd now for your niece
Because you have no daughter? O the devil!
If there be law, I'll trounce your lady Hagship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what? how now? do you taunt me, sirrah, ha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll make thee an example.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou hast made thyself an example, and the scorn of thine own child in marrying of thy drudge there; and that's the cause of her running away thou mayest think, because she hates to live where she must call her mother that was thy droil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Droil, I think, she said.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Speak to her, I charge thee, on thy obedience to speak to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The droil is now your brother's wife, madam, and in that setting your ladyship's lavish tongue aside, as good a woman as yourself, none dispraised, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-said Rachel, hold thine own Rachel. And so to you, sir sw then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, come away, mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By and by, my boy.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Do you presume to call me drudge and droil, that am a lady's sister every day in the week; and have been any time these three days, ha.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: That's not every day in a whole week yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou shalt not dare to call me sister housewife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Cod's so, and why trow? because a lady scorns to be a housewife, ha. If you be no housewife, I scorn to call
you sister, I; though my husband be your brother. From whence came you trow, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to say to the boldface.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray forsooth come away, I am afeared she'll beat you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thanks, my good child, but do not be afraid my lamb.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Boldface, ha! Her brother's wife ▪ s a boldface, but her face is not varnished over, yet like his ladysisters face, but it may be in time when she learns the trick on't, and have as many flies upon't, though not so troubled with 'em, as a bald mare at midsummer, hah.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to say to her, she has charmed the virtue of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I never heard her speak so much in all her life, sir Swithin, nor half so loud. thank heaven, she has a voice yet on a good occasion. And so far I'll maintain her in it. Nephew Nehemiah, when saw you your cousin Joyce.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O Lud, oh mother forsooth, look you, mine uncle holds me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ah, naughty man, did a so gi' ▪ me a stroke, and I'll beat it, ●h —.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Your wife has taught you to play the rude companion, has she? Pray take her home sir, and let her discipline your own child if you have one, and let mine alone. You know the way you came, sir; or if you have a mind to stay here, come sir Swithen, come away children; I hope I shall find some other room in mine own house, free from your assaults, if not, I'm sure there's law against riots. Come sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Not yet good madam nestlecock, you shall hear me.
You have enticed away, then lost my daughter.
And now you're a juggling with your widow wit,
And your small worm here, to catch up for gudgeons.
Sir Swithen and his niece, I know your plot ..
She's not fit match for you sir Swithen; and her son
Much less for your fair niece. Come dry your eyes,
And look upon him, and not only look,
But laugh at him, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: I could now for him heartily.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Mark how his mother's milk drops at his nose, while I show you the mother and the child.
He was her youngest son, and all that's left of seven, and dreaming that he needs must prove a prophet, she has bred him up a fool.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Forsooth mother he mocks me, o. —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O profane wretch, worse than thy brother Strigood.
sp.l: Do not cry, Nehemiah, peace, good boy, peace. So so.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A tender mother I must say she has been.
For till he was fifteen, none but herself
Must look his head, or wash his pretty face
For making of it cry. Laugh at her good sir Swithen.
And before that, till he was twelve years old
She would dance him on her knee, and play with's cock.

sp.speaker: Wh●m.
sp.l: Ah ah ah ah. —

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So well-said, sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Just so efac my mother would serve me, ha, ha.
Is not this better than whining.
Yes, or perhaps then wiving either.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.l: Do you say so.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Well said, sir Swithen, laugh on. I hope I ha' done a cure on him, by showing him a
more ridiculous object then himself, to turn the tide of's tears.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Laugh still, defy the fiends, women, and all their works.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, let the dead go, and the quick care for themselves. You buried your wife, and cried, and I buried mine.
sp.l: And laugh; which is the manlier passion.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He knows not that he is married again.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: You are the merriest merchant, ha, ha, ha.
I think I shall not marry again in haste, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-said, hold there. And for your niece
Let me alone. I'll fit her with a match.
I know a lad that's worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. —

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He'll laugh too much, I fear.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He may at you,
For your officiousness.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha. —

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: To thrust yourself into unthankful offices.
In things concern you not. Will you turn matchmaker
For others unentreated, 'tis enough.
For you, I hope, that you have matched yourself, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ha! Do you hab, or talk to me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Who else
Should talk or give you counsel but your wife?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well-said Rachel, hold thine own Rachel.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am matched again.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pax, cry again, or burst thyself with laughing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: La. Ha, ha, ha. Laugh son Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Ha, ha. ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What am I? what do you make of me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, what ha' you made yourself? best ask the chimney piece that you have married there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Dared thou advance a voice against me, ha?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You did commend it in me against your sister.
And I may better be familiar with you;
Ha, are you not my husband? I am sure
'Tis not so long since we were married, that
You can forget it, or repent so soon.
I am not now your slave, to have my face
Washed with your snuffs, nor to be kicked and trod on
Without resistance, nor to make you answers
Merely with silent courtesies, run when you bid go
To fetch and carry like your spaniel,
In which condition I lived long enough,
And was content until you freed me out on't.
Now free I am, and will be a free woman,
As you are a freeman, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O base-born beggar.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You wrong your wife in that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How she holds up the wife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I never begged
Nor moved a lip to be your wife, not I,
You held my service portion good enough,
And for my blood 'tis no more base than yours,
Since both are mixed in marriage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Come your way.
And let me hear you speak so much at home.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I hope I may be bolder in mine own house.
So madam, for the love I have found in yours,
You shall be welcome thither, when you're sent for.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What a bold piece of kitchen-stuff is this?
Brother you're matched.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: And catched ifacla, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He has not a word to speak.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Follow me home and durst.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes sir, I dare without more leave taking, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Was ever comb so cut.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: There's a new aunt indeed! she brought me nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: I have not laughed so much I know not when,
H'has made me laugh until I cry again.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Again, you are welcome, sir, Mrs. blithe
Now the unwelcome guests are gone, let's in
And dine, then will we after meat

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Of jointures, madam, and of nuptials treat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Right sir.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Love, as I shall adore thee for a deity.
Rid me of this ridiculous society.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Matchil, Rachel, between Erasmus and Valentine.

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.p: Good Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Mistress, be not so violent.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll rather run my country, gentlemen, then endure her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You were best to kill her then, and then you'll have no other course to take, unless you stay and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll make thee glad to fly first.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: From my house and husband shall I? from my possessions shall I? And leave you all to spend in riot shall I? No sir, I'll stay and spend my share if you go to that, that will I. And make all fly as well as you, and you go to that, that will I, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Whoop, whow.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Nay, flee be not so loud.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What didst thou bring thou drudge thou.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That which you were content to drudge withal, I am too sure of that. The drudge you speak of is no worse than your own wife, I am too sure o'that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I know not what to say to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Did you not say for better, for worse? And if 'twere worse than 'tis, 'twere all too good for you. And that I hope I shall find some good friend to know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That I like well, I'll be her first man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I trust you have found the drudge to be a woman fit to content a man, and if you grant not that, some better man perhaps shall be a judge, betwixt you and the drudge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Better still.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She threatens horns. I think.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Horns. I think, you said. If 'twere so 'twere too good for you. Cannot your own wife content you, ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She holds up that point stoutly.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That shall be tried.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O for an expert chirurgeon now to cast her in a dead sleep, and geld her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Introth you will be both sorry, when your passion gives but least way to your understandings. Mr. Matchil, let me persuade with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Never unless you bring her on her knees, to crave forgiveness at my foot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you but yield an inch he treads upon your neck, I will not give an under spur-leather for you. But bear it out bravely, and I'll be your servant.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Mrs. Matchill indeed, to be so matched.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So matched ▪ how matched? what from the hurden sinock with lockram upper-bodies, and hempen sheets, to wear and sleep in holland, and from the dripping-pan to eat in silver, ●ha. Do you repine at your match, ha. Is wealth contemptible to you?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I was better content in my poverty. I have not been myself, gentlemen, since he married me.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: You may be poor again as soon as you please, the door is open, depart at your pleasure; you know the way to your old aunt the applewoman, at hockly-hole. Take your knitting needles again, and live with her, go.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No sir, I'll stay with you, and make you as poor before I have done with ye, as I was before you had me gent. I shall not be myself till then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The devil you shall. Was ever such a crooked condition crept into a thing like woman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet this sir, is the rare piece of obedience
You boasted of, and said you would defy
The devil to dishonest her, I am sorry
Your judgement led you into such an error,
Already she's my mistress.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is she so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, and I'll call him servant, gentlewomen use it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do so, mistress.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If she, sir, be your mistress, then am I
Your master-in-law, out of my house I charge you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Dost thou conspire to grieve him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, sir, I did but jest. You have my pity.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: All are not times for jest, friend Valentine.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.p: O my affliction!

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Have a little patience, sir.
sp.l: While I talk calmly with her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Leave me then
A while unto my thoughts. Go into the house.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray servant help me here a little. Do so much
As wind up my jack for me, my watch I would say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her Jack ▪ she's in the kitchen still.
A pretty watch this, mistress, what did you pay for't.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nothing, my husband gave me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pity the spring is broke, but I can get it mended.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Good servant take it with you then to the jack-makers, I would say, the watch-makers. Come gentlemen, shall we have a crash at cards?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: With all my heart. What is your game?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can play a many old games. One and thirty bone-ace, tickle me quickly, and my lady's hole, and sichie. But you shall teach me new ones, though I lose money for my learning, gleek and primero, Gresco saut, primofistula, I know all by hearsay. Come let us have a bout at somewhat. I have money enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I'll make shift to ease you of some on't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Affliction on affliction hourly finds me,
And lays me on the rack, tearing my heart
Like greedy vultures, oh my heart, this heart
That I so long supposed impenetrable
By all the darts of sorrow, is now transfixed,
Shot through and through with torments, and by this.
This last made sensible of all the rest.
My sons untimely death, my daughter's loss.
My sister's follies, and my brother's vices.
My servant's falsehood, and the jeers of strangers
Now wound me all at once; and all through this
Predominant blow, pulled on me by mine own
Impetuous rashness. Let me here consider,
While my heart's torture keeps my soul awake,
The moving cause of all these ill effects.
Mine own unbridled wild affections.
Scorn of example, and contempt of counsel.
I cannot but observe withal, how just,
A judgement follows mine own wilful acts,
In the same kind of doing ills for ills.
For my lost son, I rashly wrought revenge
Upon an innocent girl; and with her
Have lost mine own; and for th'unmanly joy
I took in one wife's death, because a shrew.
(Though otherwise virtuous) I am in another
Trebly tormented; not alone with noise,
But with a fear of unchaste purposes,
Which if they come to act, my purse must pay for.
I see my faults, and feel the punishments.
And rather than stand out in my defence
T'enjoy some peace, I will endure some sorrow
And bear it civilly. Within there.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Go call your mistress, pray her to come alone.
My resolution brings me yet some ease:
Men that are born to serve, must seek to please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.l: Your pleasure quickly, I have left
My company, my servant, and my friend yond,
Sawing against one another at corn the caster; till I come to 'em.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And then all three to in and in, is't so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My servant, and my friend and I are e'en all one.
They are the goodest gentlemen, the best company.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your servant and your friend.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes, and my servant plays for me now in my absence, as far as ten pieces go that I left him. My plow goes there, though I am here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your plow makes vile balks of my money the while.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am not so ill a housewife as you imagine. And my friend, and my servant have promised to carry me abroad, to this town, and to that town, and tother town, and whow, I know not whither. And my servant will have me to Hyde-park he says, to see and to show all, as well as the brave gallants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is gallant indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And my friend will carry me to a what-do-you-call, a new academy, where I shall see the rarest music and dancing, he says, and learn the finest compliments. and other courtly qualities that are to be had for money, and such instructions for the newest fashions

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She will fly to the devil for fashion's sake. Pray stay a little, and let me talk calmly with you. You have almost broke my heart.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But not altogether, I hope. I would not win so great a game, without some sport in playing it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear me.
I know you put on this affected carriage,
But to try mastery, and the disease
Being so general among all women,
Is in you therefore more excusable.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O, are you coming?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear what I will say to you.
And find in that a husband's good affection.
I love my peace, and would preserve my honour,
Both which are in your breasts to save or spoil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And can you think the way to purchase peace
Is by a war with me? hah, you are cozened.
Do you think your domineering looks, or noise,
Or blows, can fright me into quietness,
Or that you shall have honour by abasing
Your wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You will not understand me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Though I love peace, and would preserve my honour.
I'll yield in both to you, and can, (I have been
So used to thraldom) but the world, the world
Is such a talker. —

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I have found the man.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There I would save a reputation.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He's loath to bring it out; I'll close w'ye.
You'll be content so, I will suffer you
To bear a loud command o'er me in public,
That I shall carry it in private. Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Truly wife, yes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You'll give me leave to beat you
In private then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, we'll bar blows at all times.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But if I chance to give you a rap or two,
Or now and then a nip, and you strike me
Again, I'll strike you some way else, as you
Would not be struck. And so observe my carriage.
The gentlemen are coming.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O, here they are.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And not by the ears: that's wonderful.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Sir, I perceive my error, and repent it.
Promising you in all my after life,
To be a faithful and obedient wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
