sp.l: He has fetch't her about, it seems.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Gramercy Rachel, bind it with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And thus it should be.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, have ye found us?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: With joy to see this reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thus shall ye see it ever, gentlemen.
I knew she would yield, or I should make her heart ache.
What were a husband, if he were not master?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have won the field, it seems, yet I may hope
I have not lost a mistress.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor I a friend.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In a fair way, gentlemen, I shall
Abridge her of no courtly privilege.
But no more haytie twaytie tricks, I charge you.
She shall not jaunt to this nor that town with you.
(I thank you for your care) nor to Hyde-park.
Nor to the academy you tell her of, without my leave.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And do you say so mistress?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Truly yes.
I am no such woman as you took me for,
With Mr. Matchil's leave you may be welcome
Home to his house in good and seemly sort.
Put pray expect no further entertainment
Than he shall well allow of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have lost her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: This change is admirable.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Why do you admire it.
Is she not mine? how could you think she durst
Stand out in her rebellion? although the devil
Who soothes all upstarts dispositions
Into an overweening of themselves.
Possessed her for a time, had not I power
And virtue do you think to conjure him out?
What have I studied for, think you, e'er since
My last wife died, but how to rule the next?
Go get you in, there's something in the house
Worth looking after.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I be sworn, he frights her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Would I had you within to perform covenants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What do you grow rebellious again.
Why stir you not else, ha? prithee sweetheart
Respect my dignity, or only seem to do it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, I will only seem to do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He makes her tremble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I must about my house-affairs.
So, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Good Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Aha.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And Mr. Matchil, at your own good pleasure.
Having in private something to impart to you,
I would entreat your presence.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Your ear before I go good Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: H'has brought her to her servile old obedience.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O — o.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: That is a private touch, sir, of the business.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pox of your lobster claws. There waanip ▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: It will be worth consideration, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, I'll come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Any ill news that you change colour so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, nothing, nothing but a womanish fear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, you are a happy man that have of her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You know not me yet gentlemen, I know a word in private would do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet she desires to have you again in private.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis her abundant love, and pure obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She comes again.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Since you're not yet disposed to cnter, sir.
One word more, Mr. Matchil, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O, — I understand you. Go, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Again, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I must wear lantern-horns upon mine arms,
If she use this. Well, gentlemen, at your own time
Let's see ye. My Rach. shall make you welcome,
And for me, you know me, I will still be master. —
I come, I come, I come. So, farewell gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha, do you run?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What dost thou think of this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll lay all the tricks I have against his brags.
She masters him in private, and that all
This show of her obedience is dissembled.
My hope revives again; we must abroad with her.
But tell me, what new academy's that
You told her of, I understand not that yet.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor have I seen it, but we both will shortly.
'Tis but of two or three days standing yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where is it? who are the professors,
And what the arts?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I'll tell thee all know.
It carries a love-sound; but I am told
It is but private lodgings kept by
Both men and women, as I am informed, after the French manner.
That profess music, dancing, fashion, compliment. —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And no drabbing?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: A little perhaps in private.
But guess now in whose house all this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Even in your city-mystresses, that lends you
Money so freely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who chameleon?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes sir, I doubt, your borrowing of the wife
Has broke the husband, put 'em off their trade,
And now they seek new ways to live by projects.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And could you keep this from me all this while,
Till I am there, each step's a tedious mile.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But not without me, good Val. We'll find a time.
Together, and our Mrs. Matchil with us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I protest cock, I commend thy course
Thou hast taken in brave lodgers, gallant guests,
Guests o'th' game cock; and my house is counted
A house of quality and recreation, cock,
in civil sort and gentle fashion, cock,
Sbobs cock, I know thou wouldst not have it otherwise
For all the wealth i'th' exchange.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But Rafe you care not
What people say, so I bring you in profit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, not I, my little cocksy nansie,
Not I, pish, honey soit qui maly pense.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Some do not stick to say, I know what's what,
And that our house is no better than it should be.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish, honey soit again, i'th' very teeth of 'em,
Let 'em all say what they will. Dainty come thou to me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But I know what I know, and that our house is
Better than it should be, if some of them
Had but the keeping of it, that speak so ill on't.
And that the gentlewomen in our house
Are well-conditioned, and as chaste as courteous.
And if you saw, (As they desire I should
See all betwixt their great resorts and them)
You'd be in love with their sweet way of living.
Then for their dancing, 'tis so neat and graceful.
See 'em anon at practice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, cock, I'll see nothing.
I will not leave one ducking pond, for ten dancing schools.
Yet I can dance, and love it: you know that cock.
And though you are a gentlewoman born,
You took me for my legs, not for my arms.
Is not that a good jest, cock. Sbobs 'twas out before
I was aware. Here comes their father.
sp.stage: Enter Strigood, Cash, disguised in bravery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It seems he has brought in some new scholar.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Where are my daughters, landlady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Close in their chamber, sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Are none of our academics come yet?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not any, sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I look for some anon
Pray bid the girls come down
To practise.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Sir, when I was a bachelor, I practised,
Dancing sometimes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Indeed, good landlord?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And maugre wedlock, I have something left
Yet in these legs, that can express at least
Love to the quality.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: That shall not be lost,
If I can further it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I saw last night
Your new French dance of three, what call you it?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I think I could make one in't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: This gentleman's another, call the music.
I'll try what you can do.
Cash, thou art welcome, I am glad I met thee.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: But that you had foreknowledge of my habit,
And seen it in my outleaps, as you call 'em,
I might ha' passed. But you in this disguise,
None but the devil himself that is your inmate,
And lodges with you in it, could have known you.
Sure he devised it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: No, you are short.
I learned it of a Jesuit.
And 'twas but easy: shaving of my old
Grey hair and beard off; clapping on this peruke
After the fashion; having but few wrinkles.
(For which I thank my bachelorship, I pass
For a brisk youth. But for my Hannibal eye here. And by my brother's
courteous advice I have taken a course to live
Upon my stock of wit, slight and activity,
With nimble brain, quick hands, and airy heels, as he told me, ha!

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: He could not think you would have stolen his daughter to ha' set up withal.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: But now I care not
What the wretch thinks, so he discovers nothing,
I dare trust thee cash, partly on thy oath
Which I have taken you know: but more respectively
Upon your forty pieces here, friend Cash,
Which I have also taken: but most of all
For that I know you dare not make discovery,
For fear of little-ease. That were a prison
Too fearful for such bravery to stoop into.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: That keeps me still in awe. 'tis well you know it.
But it is better, he has no suspicion
That I am run away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The music's ready, sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Play then, — the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Twas very well done, landlord, I protest
I love your house the better for your quality.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But if you saw me at the ducking pond,
Me and my trull.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Your trull?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I mean, my bitch, sir.
O she would ravish you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Some other time.
Here comes your wife. The news good landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: News out of France, your fame is spread abroad.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: How out of France?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Two young French gentlemen.
New come ashore, the daintiest sweetest gentlemen
That e'er I saw (Now you'll be jealous Rafe)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Are come to lodge here, having heard
It seems, that you profess French qualities.
And instantly desire to be acquainted
With you and your sweet company.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can they speak English?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: One very well: and the tother can say
Tree fransh crown for two English kiss already,
Now be jealous Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish, honey soit qui maly pense.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You can speak French, landlord.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So much as you have heard, not one word more.
I assure you but this, adieu Monsieur and so
I leave you.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will you not see the gallants Rafe?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, I won't be jealous cock, and so ▪
By the backdoor to the ducking pond. I go.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enter then landlady, where be these girls?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here they are come.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stand aside Cash, and be not yet discovered.
Now ladies, how do y'like your way of living?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I do not like it uncle.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Troth, nor I sir.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: We eat and lodge well; and we wear good clothes.
And keep our credit in the house we live in,
But what we suffer in our reputation
Abroad, is dangerously doubtful.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Here we are viewed and reviewed by all comers.
Courted and tempted too, and though we're safe
In our chaste thoughts, the impious world may say,
We are set out to common sale.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And so you are to th' utmost of his power
I dare be sworn;

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But uncle, for the time that you intend
To stay, I pray admit no new acquaintance,
Nor any more, lest I for my escape
Venture a leap two storeys deep.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha! you said?
You know I have disclosed you to no eye
That could take knowledge who or whence you are,
And for the foreign strangers, and such townsfolks
As knew us not; what need we weigh their thoughts.
Their gold is weight; let that be all we look to.
While our deserving arts and qualities
Require it from 'em. If they think us wicked,
And hope to get virginities for salary,
And pay for their deluded hopes beforehand.
What is our act but justice on their follies,
In taking of their prodigal coin?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I hope,
You deal not that way for us.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Never fear it.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But uncle, though you have taught us courtly
Gipsy tricks.
That somewhat trench upon our modesties.
Pray let it not be thought we'll sell our honesties.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Trust to my care.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And that's the way to do it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And in that care be confidently seen,
By a deserving gentleman, whom I
Present to kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I will see none.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You need not fear me, lady; for I can
But tell your father, if you slight his servant.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Bless us! what metamorphosis is this?
'Tis Cash your father's man.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Is this the habit of a merchant's prentice?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Is this the lodging of a merchant's daughter?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Has his great marriage turned my father's house
Into a sumptuous palace, that he keeps
Such costly men. Or doth the bravery
Of his late beauteous bride require such gorgeous
Attendants? Pray what office may you fill
About her person.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Will you home and see?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: We are betrayed?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Be not afraid of cash.
I know him, and he knows us. He is our friend
And we'll be his. As for his bravery
'Tis no new thing with him. I know him of old.
This suit's his worst of four.
And he's one
Of the four famous prentices o'th' time.
None of the cream and cake-boys, nor of those,
That gall their hands with stool-balls, or their catsticks,
For whitepots, pudding-pies, stewed prunes, and tansies.
To feast their titts at Islington or Hogsden.
But haunts the famous ordinaries o'th' time,
Where the best cheer, best game, best company are frequent.
Lords call him cousin at the bowling green; and the great tennis-court.
Thy father's money
Would rust else, girl. Keep thou our council Cash.
And we'll keep thine, though't be to the undoing
Of him and all the wretches of his brotherhood,
That love their money, and their base desires,
Better than blood or name.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: But can you hold
It good in any servant so to hazard
His master's livelihood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can you hold your peace?
He's wise, and saves by't all this while: he knows
His friends are bound in full two thousand pounds,
For's truth, and his true service, and perhaps,
He is not out above one thousand yet,
Where's your wit now?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Mistress, I'll do you service, and be true to you.
I'd not have missed of this discovery. —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You see she hearkens to him. Talk aside Cash.
And touch her boldly.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I would not have missed it.
For all the wealth your father has: and at
Convenient privacy. I'll give you reasons,
That shall gain your belief to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: The French gallants.
I had almost forgotten them. They are a pair
Of delicate young monsieurs. If they have
But crowns enough, they are the likeliest
merchants for my new mart that I can choose.
She said they can speak English, that's a help.
For devil of French have I to entertain 'em.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: See mine own heart, here's more temptation still.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I'll not endure the onset.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I le defend you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Yet there are graces in their looks methinks,
That do invite my stay.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Not intends vous, la langue francois monsieur dittez.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I would be glad to hear you speak the language
I better understand, and that is English.
In which you are most welcome.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Your fair courtesy
Merits our greatest thanks.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: I tanck you, sir.
I have bid France adieu to come and learn
De English very well; I speak a lietel,
But de English mistress can teach de best.
I shall be glad to take my commencements,
Or my first lessons from these ladies' lips.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: A fine forward spark?

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: O sweet, oh delicate.
Ladies, if you will breathe into me English,
I shall, if you please, put fransh into you.
Une pour l'antre, dat is one for another.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: So they might make a hot bargain on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Are these your civil gentlemen, landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: He seems a little waggish: but the other
Is wondrous civil. He comes blushingly.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: You are before me in the salutation
Of these fair ladies, monsieur galliard:

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Il e'vray monsieur Papilion, I kiss before, than you mose kiss behind.
But let me pray my tardiness be excused

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You pronounce English well sir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I am glad
You like it lady.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I like the others as well.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I have before spent many months in England:
And my great love unto the nation,
Especially to the beauties of your sex,
Retracts me hither, where my friend was never.
Till now that my persuasion won his company;
And happily, I suppose, we are arrived:
That, to the sight and knowledge we have had
Of music, dances, courtships, and behaviour.
Through all parts of our country, France, with an
Addition of all Italy affords.
Where (By all best opinions) even the choicest
Of such court qualities, and active graces,
Have had their spring, we now, as fame suggests,
Shall in this fair society, discern
More than by all our former observation.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Report, sir, speaks too loud on our behalf,
And let me pray ye, that it not beget
Too great an expectation on our weakness,
By your too gentle suffrage. What we can,
We'll do.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: O we dats de best. Do is de ting
De Fransh man loves: if all your both two daughters
Show all; all makes but more desire to do.
Speak I no good English, mademoiselle?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: You no understand me,
Because you tinck I lie. But if you lie
With me, I make you understand me presently.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: This hot-reined monsieur takes 'em for the same.
Strigood would have 'em be I came in time.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: At afternoon we'll have an exercise
Of courtship, gentlemen. In the interim,
If you will have to stir the appetite,
A dance before our ordinary we are for you.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: And we for you Alloun all Egremant Alloun
Monsieur Papillion pour l' honour de France.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: What are your dances chiefly in request.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Good landlady, bid the music be in readiness.
And then see dinner set upon the table.
We have sir for corants, — la miniard,
La Vemimde, le marquess, le holland,
La Britain, le roy, le prince, le Montague,
The saraband; the canaries, la reveree.
For galliards, the sellibrand, the dolphin,
The new galliard, the valette galliard and lepees,

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: 'Tis all very good monsieur Papillica Essontes
Mon Amy.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And hark you, monsieur Strigood, you will be put to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I fear no French flashes. Bear up cash. If we cannot dance 'em of of their legs, our wenches can,
I warrant thee. Music be ready.
Gallants, what are you pleased to dance?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tells what, etc.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Gentlemen, your dinner stays meat will be cold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And we are hot, 'tis better that take cold then we.
But come, one table for us all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stri. Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I say so too.
But to myself reserve what I will do.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Ephraim, thou hast made me a man, both without, witness this sword and within, witness this precious book, which I have gotten almost by heart already.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: But sir, beware you fall not back again into your childish follies: but go forwards in manly actions: for non progredi est regredi.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I know the meaning of that too, Ephraim. That's once a man and twice a child. But if I turn child again, while I have teeth in my head, I'll give Mrs. blithe leave to dig 'em out with sugar-plums, as she almost did these two of 'em yesterday, with her knuckles. I would they stuck both in her bum for't, till I were married to her, and that shall be shortly, they say, I wo' not turn boy again for that trick.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope you will not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p:
Thou mayest be sure on't Ephraim: for if I would turn boy again, I ha' not wherewithal to set up again. Thou sawest that, as soon as I had tasted the sweetness of this delicious book here, I tore and burned all my ballads, as well the godly as the ungodly. In my conscience as many as might have furnished three Bartholomew fairs, and then for love of this sword, I broke and did away all my storehouse of tops, gigs, b●l●s, cat and catsticks, potguns, key-guns, trunks, tillers, and all; and will I turn boy again canst think? yet I am half sorry, being towards a wife, that I did
not keep 'em for my children: some money might have been saved by't. And that is a manly and a good husbandly consideration, I take it. But hang covetousness: there comes not a mouth into the world, but there's meat for 't; and if I find 'em not play games, their mother will find friends, that shall, for them and herself too

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear such good things to come from you,
And hope that now your judgment's strong enough
To manage my affair. You know my mind, sir.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Amardla Ephraim, 'twill be hard to compass. For the old knight will never let me have his niece, unless he have my mother. He means to truck for her, though, I confess, I had rather call thee father then any man, I know, yet I know not how to bring it about, unless he marry her first; and than she be weary of him, and take thee afterwards to mend her match. I think it must be so, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Now you fly out again, that's as impossible, as 'tis unlawful.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Within. Negh. Negh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Peace, my mother comes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Where are you child? Neh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I hear her neighing after me, I'll do all I can for thee, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Look you son, what kind sir Swithin has sent you. A dancing frog, you would think it were alive, and a ballet of burning the false prophets before they be tried. And another fearful one of the new Antichrist.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Hang baubles, burn ballets, I am a man, and defy boys tricks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A sudden change, I pray it be good.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Tell me of toys? I have a sword: offer me ballets? I have a book. Speak to me of sir Swithin, I'll talk to you of Ephraim that gave me these blessings; and is fitter to be my father, (So he is) than the foolishest knight of 'em all.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bless my son from too much learning. That book has done him no good, I doubt. He talks and looks so wildly o'the sudden.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A ha!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What book is't. Let me see it.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I'll tell you first. It is a book all of bulls, jests and lies collected by an A. s. gent. Mother forsooth, there be such things in it! If you never read it, it is the rarest book that ever you read in your life. Open it where you will, and you shall learn something. As here now. One refusing to eat cheesecakes, was asked his reason. He told them he loved the flesh well, but was afeard of the bones. Then here's the next to't. One asking whence lobsters were brought: his fellow replied, one might easily know their country by their coat. They are fetch't from the red sea. Now would I might never eat more of 'em, as well as I love 'em, if I know what cheesecakes were made of, or from whence lobsters came before.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is this your book-learning? In troth thou mak'st me laugh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Laugh on, good mother. And while you are in the merry mood, let me speak a good word for Ephraim. I have a mind forsooth, because he has made me a man, to make him my father, forsooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! How now.
How durst you sirrah, move my son in this? ha.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is it but so? ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray forsooth hear him speak. He can speak poetry (He says) as well as knight Whimlbie. Speak Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, fa●re truth have told
That Queens of old
Have now and then
Married with private men.
A countess was no blusher,
To wed her usher.
Without remorse
A lady took her horse -
Keeper in wedlock. These did wisely know,
Inferior men best could their work below.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother forsooth, is it not fine?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Nay, madam, more than so, I'll further go

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But you shall not, sirrah. What, what! how now! Is't but up and ride? ha! Out of my doors thou varlet.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I must out too then, mother I am afraid, o. —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Good Neh. be pacified, I'll give him a better answer.
sp.l: But not a word on't now, sweet child, I pray thee.
Here comes sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, madam, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I marry sir Swithin. This is better than oh madam, oh —, when you washed your handkerchiefs in the suds, and then to wring hem out in poetry.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p:
My tears with the memory of the dead are all fallen into Lethe; and nothing but joy left in me, since my hopes are confirmed in your lap. And hang
poetry: I study profit now. Therefore, look you, madam, here is a draught of my marriage-instrument to your lap.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: His instrument being drawn, I must put up my pipe and be gone.

sp.speaker: Vvhi.
sp.p: And here is another draught for sweet master Nehemiah, for my niece Blithe's jointure.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O but she says she will not have me.

sp.speaker: Vvhi.
sp.p: When did she say so?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Now, now, she spat the word out of her mouth. And I say, if she ha' not me, you shall whine both your eyes out before you have my mother; and see never the worse, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A cross marriage, or no marriage, I say still.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I say so too, son, sweet boy, be content.

sp.speaker: Whi. blithe.
sp.p: You spoke well of him behind his back: and made me think you loved him, and would marry him.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Behind his back, I may do much to please you. But when I look upon him, he turns my stomach worse than a fool made of sour milk.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Marry gip, Mrs queasy, my son's as sweet as you, I hope, and as wise as you. And sucked as sweet milk as ever the good cow your mother gave.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Patience, good madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope the cross marriage is crossed. This is untoward wooing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Uds so! do you flirt out your unsavoury comparisons upon my son?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Flirt not you at me, madam, lest I flirt your milksop under the snotty nose here.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Yes, and I have a sword, and you ha' got never a one.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You wo' not will you, ha! Do you fly at him, ha!

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Fear not, good madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ephraim, save my boy.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. —

sp.speaker: Whi
sp.p: She shall not hurt him. Leave her to me, good madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ever feared he was not long-lived he was so witty. And now I fear, she will be the death of him. I would not he should marry her for a million.

sp.speaker: Neh
sp.p: Say not so, mother. I love her better and better still.
I never had playfellow i' my life, but we fell out and in again.
And I must and will marry her, I take my death on't aforehand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O me! he is bewitched to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Leave all to me, dear madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: As I am to you, I think, sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Let me alone with her: I'll win her, and he shall wear her ▪ fear not. As I was saying, madam, she speaks as well of him behind his back, as your own heart can wish. And told me she was content to marry him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Behind his back? did she so?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes truly, madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Lo you there, mother, let her marry me behind my back then: and when we are married, I'll make her stick to't before my face, I warrant you; or if she will make back-play. I'll play at nothing but backgammons with her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, heaven bless thee, thou art but too good for her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Speak gently, niece, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Madam, I hope your ladyship shall find me too good for him. If e'er he has me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ha! say you so?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She means in well-doing, madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay then, I thank you Mrs. blithe. Assuring you that you shall be no way so good to him, but I will be as good to you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Agreed again of all hands. But look how she turns and keeps cut like my sparrow. She will be my back sweetheart still I see, and love me behind.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She is yet raw, and has not much been abroad to see the manners of the time. In which my melancholy has been her main hindrance. But madam, there is now that is worth all our sight and observation; a new academy, where they say, the newest and most courtly carriage and behaviour is taught and practised both for young gentlemen and women. Have you not heard on t?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes sir Swithin; and that the French tongue is taught there with great alacrity; and my son is wished thither, but soft I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: But let him see it: at least in our company it will embolden him; I mean to carry my niece thither. I have been a lover of arts and exercises; and know somewhat since my youth. Pray let us spend one hour of this afternoon there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pardon me good sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: But he shall not mother if you love me: for I mean to perfect my dancing there; and to learn French there; for I mean when I am married to travel into France. But I will first be perfect in the tongue I shall learn it the sooner when I am there you know. Pray let us go to th' a comedy, what d'ye call it?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: The academy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you so son? then come sir Swithin. Come Mrs. blithe, we will all go.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: I'll wait upon you, though my heart says no.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O mine own heart! how near were we both fallen
Into the gulf of ruin?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thanks for our delivery!
We were upon the brink of main destruction.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Was ever such a friend as this mine uncle?
Pretending us his children too, and called us daughters
To those he bargained with to sell our maidenhead ?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: 'Twas a most damnable practice fie upon him.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And had the monsieurs been as capable
Of our virginities, as he was of.
Their moneys, how had we then resisted.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: By Venus (Mine own heart) my gentleman
Came up so close to me, that if my voice
Had not been stronger than mine arms (Oh me!
I tremble son it yet) I had been vanquished,

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But did you note the virtue of the gentlemen?
When they were sensible of our fears and tears,
How gently they desisted and with what humanity,
When they perceived how we had been betrayed,
They pitied our conditions; and wooed homditly
Our loves in way of marriage. Provided that
Our births and fortunes might no way disparage
Theirs, being free and generous

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I confess
I love 'em both so well, that if they prove
(As they pretend they are not) our inferiors
In blood and worth, I would take either of 'em.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Troth (Mine own heart) 'tis just the same with me.
I care not which I have. And mark a sympathy,
How equally all our affections strike.
We both love them, they both love us alike.
But peace. Cash, though he has done us good service,
Must not know all. How goes it within cash?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And why cash pray. Have not you changed your names
From Joyce and Gabriella to Jane and Frances.
And is not your uncle Strigood now become
Your father, by the name of Mr. Lightfoot
The nimble dancing master? And must I still
Carry the name of cash? and having lost
My nature too, in having no cash left?
(Pox o'the dice) call me Mr. Outlash.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: My father will fetch you home with an inlash,
One o'these days.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: But after you, fair mistress,
Now to your question for the squares within.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I with the Frenchmen, and my uncle Strigood.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Your father lightfoot, you forget again.
There's a drawn match made: for the monsieurs
Have taken their money again: and you have still
Your maidenheads, I hope. But to have heard
The coi●e they kept, the wrangle, and the stir;
And how the young blades put the old one to't;
Would ha' perplexed you more than keeping of
Your maidenheads from men you love.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: You cannot tell that.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: O how the old man chafes that you would offer
To make your moan to them to move their pity,
And not to make his bargain good; and then
how they put home his baseness to him; to make sale
Of his own blood and honour in his children.
(They knew they said some parents in their country,
After their children were turned whores, would share
To live upon the profits, but to sell
Their souls before they were damned, fie; fie, fie, fie).
Till he confessed indeed you were none of his.
But children of some friends of his deceased,
Left to his care for breeding; which he had
Plenteously given, and thought it might seem reasonable
To raise his money out of you again.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: What an old devil is this?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Baser and baser still.
The monsieurs cried, and swore if they could find
Your parents were gentle and virtuous,
Being their first loves, they would marry you,
To free you from this miserable thraldom.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Brave honest gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Be advised though, mistress.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I hope I shall.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Beware of travellers, many pass abroad
For gallant fellows that have run their country,
For picking pockets.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And some you know at home
For cozening their masters.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You are pleased.
But you have known my love; for Gabriella
Let 'em share her betwixt 'em. You and I
Made one, may soon make peace with the old man
At home.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O rogue! I'll tell you more anon Cash.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, monsieur Papillion.
And monsieur Galliard, all friends, all friends.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Agreed , agreed, sir.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: And agree for me.
Agree poor tout.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Cheer up your faces girls.
'Twas but my trial of your chastity.
And since you have stood firm, I am proud of you.
Trust me, 'twas but to try you.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: We we all, but for try. Trimount, trimount.
No more, but all for try: no man can tinck,
But 'twas too very moshe to take two hundred
Crowns for two pusillages, no, no was but
For try: but and she had not squeak and scrash too
Like to do leetel chat, I had Trimount
One, two, tree, five time, for all your try.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: What's past let be forgotten. According to
Agreement, gentlemen, you're now content
To join with us in academic fellowship,
And for your pastime profess art and science,
As we do for our profit: you're expert,
I find; and shall win wonder of our nation,
To your own much delight out of their follies.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: And then for gamesters, gentlemen. If you'll play.
I'll bring ye those shall venture money enough.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: We are planted to our wish.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: All very good.
All very good; but I would see thee first.
What ladies will come here to practise compliment.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You are still hot upon the female Monsieur galliard
Monsieur Papillion here flies over them.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, the news?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: The old will to't.
As well as the young I see.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: To what landlady?
sp.stage: He takes her aside. And that while the young men and maids court and confer at tother side.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: To fashion following;
A reverend lady
Of fifty five; and a knight of threescore
And upwards, are come hither to learn fashion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Do you know their names?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, yes: and them; 'tis that
Begets my wonder.
'Tis the lady nestlecock, and one sir Swithin Whimlby.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Wit be merciful unto us.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: The lady's man's without: who came to know if the house were ready to entertain 'em; do you know 'em Mr. Lightfoot?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I have heard o'th' lady. Cash, see if it be Ephraim.
He cannot know thee. Let him not away,
By any means, his not return to them may keep 'em back.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I see him hither.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, is your husband come from ducking.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, overjoyed with the good sport he has had.
He'll play th' good fellow then. Entreat him Cash.
To help thee, put a cup or two upon
That fellow; and hear'st me, spice his cup,
I mean, grave Ephraim's cup with this same powder,
'Twill lay him asleep, and quickly.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I know the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And landlady, when the knight and lady come,
Say we are ready for 'em.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: 'Tis then an absolute contract. I am yours.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And I am yours as firm as faith can bind.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: To which we are de witness. Be so for us,
I am her husband, and she is my wife,
Speak you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Before heaven, I do acknowledge it,
But sir, the church must be observed,

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: For that.
We'll send for one minister that shall marry
Us all at once. One kiss till then shall serve.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well done monsieurs, I no sooner turn
My back, but you are on the damosels lips.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: A little in de honest way will serve,
But he shall know no-ting.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: On with your masques-maids,
And take especial heed you blush not through 'em.
For here are some at hand will put us to't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: 'Tis not my father, nor my lady aunt?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I cannot promise you. Be bold and safe.
Bear it out bravely, or our school breaks up
Immediately: and we are broke forever,
Besides, there is no starting.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: That's enough
To make a coward fight, and mine own heart;
We must stand stoutly to't, we lose our loves else.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Well, I am armed.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Fall into compliment.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I muse we lost my man thus.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: By your leave, sir.
Are you the regent of this academy?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I am sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: And are those of your assistants.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes sir, and all professors of court-discipline,
By the most accurate, yet more familiar
Rules, then have ever yet been taught by any,
For quick instruction both of young and old.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: You promise very fairly. For us old ones,
We know and could have done things in our youth,
Which still we have a mind to: but we leave
The practice to our young ones: here's a pair
Would fain be at it. We'll pay their admittance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But I'd be glad to see first by your leave,
Some probability of what they shall learn.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And reason good, good madam. Pray observe there.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Fair star of courtship, my unworthy humble self, a profest servant to the integrity of beauty, makes this
Clear testimony of your merits, that every eye that sees you,
Owes you his heart for tribute, and that unjustly your beholders live, that live not in your service.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother forsooth, is not this French?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peace child. Hear more on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: Noble sir, you are so exactly deserving in the opinion of all righteous judgements, that the least syllable of your fair testimony, is able to re-edify the ruins of a decayed commendation.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: The best that ever I heard, since I wooed my Grissel.

sp.speaker: Stri,
sp.p: Was not that a sweet bout, sir?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, it puts me in mind of some sweet bouts I had with one before I married her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Has he married my sister trow?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: I am forced to give you over, madam, you have such a preventing and preoccupying wit in all things.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: That goes like English Mrs. blithe. I could learn some of that methinks .

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Best tell your mother so; she may rejoice at it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: There, lady, was a taste of sweet compliment between persons equally affected. May it please you now to let your son pass upon this demosel. Who being to her a stranger, and raw (As I imagine) in courtship, shall meet with reprehension, that may be for his instruction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do Neh. speak to her.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Put of your hat and say —.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What! and her mask on?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That was well-said. Why are they masked, I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We are commanded it by the policy of wise authority; for fear young heirs might fall in love with 'em, and sink their fortunes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You have well satisfied me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What should I say to one I never saw.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: When I was young and bold, I would have said, lady, you are most auspiciously encountered. And speak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Lady, you are most suspiciously accoutred, I speak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Auspiciously encountered man.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Auspicously encountered woman, I say.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I commiserate your encounter. 'tis a most hungry, verminous, impoverished word sir. It seems you are a stranger by't, to the innovation of courtship.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What should I say to that now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He's a weak scholar forsooth, and would be glad to learn.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: The acknowledgement of his weakness is the first grease of gradation to perfection, and his gladness the scaling-ladder of resolution.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray forsooth, can you teach me a compliment to offer you sugar-plums, and eat 'em myself: to save my manners and my plums too?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What a wag it is?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What walking dunghill is this? made of the dust swept from the house of ignorance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! how now, ha? you are a flapse to term my son so, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O good madam. This is but school play.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I'll put her by her school-tricks and no only unmask, but unskin her face too, and she come over my heir apparent with such Billingsgate compliments.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Sweet madam, no harm was meant, and nothing said in earnest: 'twas merely but school practice, but to show the sweet young gentleman how he might be subject to the scorn of court, before he be seen in compliment.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: 'Twas told your ladyship before, that by reprehension he might find instruction.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Right madam; for no fencer learns his science before he receive some hits and knocks too: o, I have had many.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, I am satisfied, and pray, that my rash error may prove pardonable lady

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Rather let me implore your mercy, madam —.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
'Tis well, 'tis well let's hear an interchange or two now, of complemental acknowledgement of
courtesies passed betwixt ladies, for the edification of this fair one, who seems not yet to have taken notice of us, but looks of the ground still.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: 'Tis not to find a fescue, sir, among the rushes.
To pick out a lesson in your criss-cross-row of compliment.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sharp and sudden. She has a good wit I see.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ob , good blithe, observe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Can your poor servant express acknowledgement enough, lady, for favour so incessantly heaped upon her, besides the accumulation of many secret benefits?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: I cannot but admire, madam, your noble and illustrious gratitude, that can give beauty to benefits of so low a birth and condition.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: O my Grissel comes to my mind again, she was the gratefullest woman.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: If such favours, madam, should pass under an humble name, honour would grow idle, and a thankful nature beguiled of her employment.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You'll make my zeal hereafter, too bashful to serve your most curious acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Curious acknowledgement! There was a thread drawn out.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am hound by many kindnesses, madam, to celebrate the fair memory of you; as the trouble of your coach twice in one day, besides those inestimable jewels, the monkey and dormouse your ladyship sent me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I would you could lend me a sight of 'em forsooth, I love such things devoutly.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You do but open a privy door to my thankful remembrance, madam, for the bounty of your squirrel and paraquito.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Fagh, shut that privy-door.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And shut in the squirrel and the paraquito to be stifled, shall she? O that I could see hem!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Now madam, and sir knight, is not this neat and handsome?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Truly, truly, 'tis most admirable pretty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Nay, if you heard our lectures, saw our
Dances.
Relished our music and harmonious voices,
Observed our rules for fashion and attire,
Our many exact postures and dimensions,
Fit to be used by way of salutation,
Of courtesy, of honour, of obeisance,
To all degrees of man or womankind,
From the low bent of vassalage, to the head
Of towering majesty, you should admire.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But do you read and teach all these to your scholars?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Stand forth, monsieur galliard. Stay we're interrupted.
sp.l: Up maids, and quickly; or 'tis not your masques
Can keep you undiscovered. Go, be ready,
With music and your voices, when I call to ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why are we interrupted? pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, it is my naughty aunt, so 'tis ▪

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No matter, son, we'll take no notice of her.
sp.l: I wonder at the boldness of the drudge though.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can turn tail too, as well as the great lady. Hab.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And do so, mistress, give her a broadside.
sp.l: Well-said, we'll make our party good, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sir, we have heard your fame; and love your arts.
〈◊〉 pray that our ambition be excused,
Which drew on our intrusion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: To me and to the place you are all welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And so to all I hope, chiefly to you,
Good madam dowager, hoping in good time
I may get good, by doing much good upon you
How likes your lordship my compliment.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you bring your rude companions to affront me? Are you so hot? you stir up your cinders before they be caked.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Still in the kitchen-dialect.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No ruder than yourself, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I brought her, madam,
sp.l: 〈◊〉 advance my suit to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Will you see me abused
Sir 〈◊〉, look to your niece, the tother talks to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Kind merry gentlemen, madam, when I was young I would have done the like. Their coming hither, was as ours was to note th' instructions
That are taught here. Pray sir proceed. On with your exercise, that we may all be edified.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We shall do so, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But sir, your gentlewomen,
sp.l: That passed upon our entrance where are they?

sp.p: Sir, they were called in haste to private practice
sp.l: With some great ladies in an upper room.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Umh — private practice. Well, I shall know all.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And they being absent, we shall for the present
sp.l: Only deliver by these gentlemen,
●●me heads of sciences.
A song, a dance, and then
Entreat you take a taste of a collation.
And all most fairly welcome.
The heads of our chief arts. Your silence, pray you.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: The first is the due carriage of the body,
The proper motion of the head, hand, leg,
To every several degree of person,
From the peasant unto the potentate;
To your inferiours how and when to use the nod,
The hum, the ha, the frown, the smile,
Upon the fit occasion; and to your equals,
The exactest, newest, and familiar motions
Of eye, of hand, of knee, of arm and shoulder,
That are in garb, in congee, cringe, or shrug,
In common courtesy, or compliment,
Lastly, for your addresses to superiors.
The honours, reverence, or obeisances,
Proper unto the quality or estate
Of person whatsoever. And so much
For carriage and behaviour. In the next place
You shall have rules for the more graceful wearing
Of your apparel, with the natural reasons,
Why some man's hat does better in his hand
Then on his head, and why his coat hangs neater
Upon his elbow, then upon his back,
As also reasons for tunes bringing up.
And marriages, together of the fashions
Of man and woman, how his caller, and her
Black-bag, came on together; how his pocket-comb
To spruce his peruke, and her girdle-glass,
To order her black pashes, came together;
How his walking in the streets without a cloak
And her, without a man came up together,
Of these, and of a hundred more the like.
We shall demonstrate reasons and instructions.
Shall render you most graceful in each fashion.
The next are skills in instruments, song and dancing

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enough, those shall be made familiar to you
By voice and action instantly. A song there.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Admirable pretty still.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Are these your gentlewomen's voices, sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: They are

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What do you keep 'em up like nuns,
To sing and not be seen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Not always sir.
But may it please ye gentlemen and ladies,
Now to observe the practice of our feet
In active dancing.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: That came I to learn,
And to speak French, do you think sir, you can bring
My mouth to handle the French tongue handsomely.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He's apt to learn, sir, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.p: Yes. I shall bring his mout to it. But his mont is yet a little too wide. But he shall have some of de water datde woman use for anoderting, to bring it better together, and he shall speak like de Fransh lady.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray sir, if you can like the lady's daughter of Paris properly.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. thou knowest the way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder sir, 'mongst all your arts and sciences
You have so little judgement in a face,
Does his mouth appear wide to you? what false glass
Are your eyes made of?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What you mean?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, friend.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Pray sir take no offence. Here was none meant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Slander is no offence then. He has injured,
By breathing an aspersion on that face,
The life of beauty, and the soul of sweetness.
Wide mouth y —.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Begar monsieur, you shall no point out mouth,
No, nor outface the French man with your great bull-beef, and mustard English looks.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, gentle Val. forbear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll stop.
This mouth that knowingly says he dares except
Against a tittle of his face or person.
But as he is an ignorant stranger, and
I must respect the company. I forbear.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: However sir, I can but thank your love in 't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now it works in her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pardon my plainness, madam.
I never was so taken with masculine beauty.
And till I win a woman that is like him,
Or has been like him, I can but languish.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They told me I was like him, when I was younger.
And let me tell you you're a comely gentleman.
And be you but as honest as you're handsome, you deserve well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Umh, 'tis a hard matter to bring those ends together.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother forsooth. Here's a man now for you to make my father!
Beyond the knight or Ephraim!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Were I free from the old knight, I could look well upon him.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Come servant, come away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By no means, mistress, I do but soothe her up to jeer her for you.
If you outstay her not, you lose your honour.
She'll brag she has outlooked you. If you start.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Nay, and she go to that, I hope I can,
Look as ill favouredly as herself, or a better
Woman than she, and stay in spite of her, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, mistress, madam shall I tell you.
But I would pray you not to storm, but laugh at it.
She says you are no match for me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And knowing I aim at none but some great widow.
Tells me she knows her husband's but short-lived.
I fear she means to break his heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No words, good madam.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: ●et more whispering.
Pray madam let us go. Niece come away,
For I fear madam, as you wisely doubted,
This is no company for us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, I hope.
I am not yet so tied, but I may safely
Use my own freedom, I'll go when I please.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: O Grissel, Grissel, when wouldst thou have said so?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Love's power, I hope, hath won on destiny,
To appoint this day for my delivery.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, good sir Swithin, — ladies — we have yet
Dancing to come, and a collation promised.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes gallants, now w' are ready, we but stayed for this fourth man here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O chameleon.
Where is your wife? I hope your je lousy.
Locks her not up.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pish honi soit. I hate it.
No, she has been preparing of a banquet,
Which now is ready for you, worthy Mr. Lightfoot,
And your fair company; jealousy I defy
The ba●e horn ague , Mr. Askal I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What does he call you? Rascal?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Askal madam.
My name is Askal. But the R in master
Runs in●oed so, that sometimes it sounds doubtful.
I must be knighted, euphoniae gratia.
Sir Valentine Askal will come fairly off.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now note me Mr. Askal, and tell me if ever jealous man came so lightly off.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Sir, your collation stays.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well, gallants and ladies
Will't please you enter.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, of all sides.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Inhospitable! 'tis inhumane, passed
The cruelty of infidels.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou speak'st
But thine own barbarous cruelty, hollow Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Abominable hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Cunning villain.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Fie gentlemen, forbear this unknown language.
And either speak to others understanding,
If you speak justice:

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Give me then my son.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Thou hast thy son, give me my son and daughter.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pray gentlemen, if you'll not hear each other, yet both hear me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I pray captain speak.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You had his son to foster; he your daughter.
You faithfully affirm you sent his son
For England a month since.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: And mine own with him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You have confessed you put away his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And mine own with her, through her disobedience.
But 'twas upon advertisement by letter,
That he had first cast off my son to an
Untimely death.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Some villain forged that letter,
And let me tell you sir, though in your house,
Lafoy's an honest and a temperate man.
You are rash and unadvised, what Lafoy speaks
I will maintain for truth: what you have done
I wish you could make good; but I may fear
You are marked out by your own wilfulness,
The subject of much woe and sad misfortune.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not what I am; but did you know
The number, and the weight of my afflictions,
You could not chide me thus without some pity.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Indeed I pity you, and now you're calm,
Know that Lafoy sent his son over with yours,
And but for some affairs he had with me,
I'th isle of wight he had embarked himself
With them, and brought hem to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There's hope then yet
That my boy lives.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And is come over fear not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You comfort me, and now Lafoy you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: But to what comfort, having lost my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Lost or lost not, mine's with her. And I
Purpose now to be sad no longer. For I think
I ha' lost my wife too, there's a second comfort.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Take an example here Monsieur Lafoy,
And shake of sadness; mirth may come unlooked for.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I ha' lost a son too, a wild roaring lad,
About this town. And if I find not him,
I doubt not I shall find, that he has spent me
A hundred pound since I last heard of him.
By the way sir, I sent you a bill of change
Last month, to pay a hundred pieces for me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Twas paid. I have your bill for my discharge.
How now?
Have you found your mistress.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Nor tidings of her, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She has found then some good exercise, I doubt not.
That holds her so.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, there's a gentleman
Craves instant speech with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Who? or whence comes he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: He will be known to none before he sees you.
And, when you see him, he says he thinks you'll know him.
He's a brave gallant, one o'the alamodes,
Nothing but French all over.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fetch him me quickly,
it is my son. Gramercy mine own heart,
That waste not light so suddenly for nothing,
Pray gentlemen, whoe'er you see, name no man
To me, unless I ask you. He comes, he comes.
I'm grown a proper man. Heaven make me thankful.
Just such a spark was I at two and twenty,
Set clothes and fashion by. He thinks to try
If I can know him now. But there I'll fit him.
With me sir is your business?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I presume
You do not know me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: As well as he that got him.
Pray gentlemen keep your countenances. Not know you sir?
'Tis like I may have known you to ,
But cannot readily collect; perhaps
You are much changed by travel, time, and bravery,
Since I last saw you. There he may find.
I partly guess, but will not know him yet.
Good gentlemen say nothing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What ails he trow.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: He knows me, I fear, too soon. If now my plot fail, and he have a counterplot upon me. I am laid up.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Do you not know me yet sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Know you, or know you not sir, what's your business.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: You sometimes had a son sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes to me.
I had sir. But I hear he's slain in France.
And farewell he. Mark how I handle him.
And what sir of my son?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: He's dead you say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I muse the knave asks me not blessing though.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: But to supply his loss you have a daughter
That may endear a son, sir, to your comfort.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whither now flies he trow! Sir, do you know her.
Or where to find her?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: First upon my knees
Let me implore your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes home: and I can hold no longer.
My blessing boy, thou meanest. Take it, and welcome
To a glad father. Rise, and let my tears,
If joy confirm thy welcome.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I may not rise yet sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No? why? what hast thou done? where's young Lafoy?
My true friend's son here? whom I now must lock
Up in these arms, amid a thousand welcomes.
Where's the young man?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I know not who you mean sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Distract me not.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: I fear you are destraught.
I know not him. How should he know my son.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let me look nearer.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Sir, I am your prentice.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whow — whow, whow, who — my thief and runaway.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Prav sir afford me hearing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, your cause
Requires a judge's hearing.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I have put me
Into your hands, and not without much hope,
To gain your pardon, and your daughter's love.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis roundly spoken. Gentlemen, I'll tell you.
This gallant youth, has gallanted away
A thousand pound of mine.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: For your advantage sir: for
By this way
Of gallantry, as you call it, I have travelled
Through the resorts and haunts public and private
Of all the gallants in the town. In brief
I have found your daughter, where she had been lost
For ever in your brother Strigood's hands.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Canst bring me thither?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Is my daughter with her?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Madam Gabriella, the French damsel's there.
And others, men and women, whom you'll know when you come there.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Good sir, let's hasten thither.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You'll aid me, sirs?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes, with our lives and fortune.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be fearless lady, and upon my life,
Honour, and faith; you are secure from danger.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Sir, I have put me in your hands you see
So liberally that I may fear to suffer,
If not a censure, yet a supposition
Of too much easiness, in being led
So suddenly so far towards your desire.
But my opinion of your nobleness
Joined with your protestation, pleads my pardon
at least it may, the wretchedness considered,
To which I was enthralled.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: It is not more my love
Unto your virtue, and your fair endowments.
Then pity in me labours your release.
Nor is it rather to enrich myself.
Then to save you from so immense a danger,
As you had fallen into by yielding under
Your uncle's weakness in so fond a match.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Bless me from being fool-cloged.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now you are free.
If you can think yourself so, and but yield
Unto my present counsel.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do so lady
Before you are missed within. Here is the closet,
And here's the key in your own hands, and presently I'll fetch a priest.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You see
I still deal fairly w'ye; and give you power
To keep guard on yourself.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: And yet I yield
Myself your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In: somebody comes.
She will be yours. And let me tell you, sir,
I wish you as much joy with her, as I
Have with my cock.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You have befriended me
In this good enterprise: and one good turn
Requires another. And now for that I told you,
Touching your wife, your cock you so rejoice in.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas. alas, good gentlemen, you would fain
Have me be jealous. Honi soit, you're short.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Stand by and observe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you begin to boggle,
And when I send for twenty pieces, do you
Send me but ten?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay mark.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray,
What have I had in all by your account.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: At several times, you have had fifty pounds of my poor husband's money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What's that to the free pleasure of my body
Which must afford you sweet and lusty payment?
You froward monkey. But perhaps you ha' got
Some new-found horn-maker, that you may think,
Deserves your husband's money better, for
Doing his journeywork, one o'the monsieurs,
Or both perhaps i'th' house here under's antlers,
It must be so, why else of all the town,
Must I be one o'th' last that must take notice
Of your new college here, your brazen face college
Of feats and fine vagaries? do you grow weary of me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Do you grow wild? speak lower, do you mean to undo me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will tother fifty pound undo thee, I have lost
All that I had within among your monsieurs.
And you must yield supply, or lose a friend
Of me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What a way would so much money have gone
In bets at the ducking pond?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will no less serve your turn then fifty?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No less. All makes (You know) but a just hundred.
And there I'll stick; and stick close to thee too,
Else all flies open. What care I who knows
your credit's breach, when you respect not mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis too well known already; all's too open.
My house, my purse, my wife, and all's too open.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: O me, undone.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Was ever loving husband
So much abused?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Inquire among your neighbours.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be patient man.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O thou close whore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take heed, sir, what you say.
E'en now you said she was too open, sir.
You're in two tales already.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I fear he's mad
Or jealous, which is worse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pish, honi soit.
He jealous, he defies it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do you deride me?
Sir, you can witness with me, he confessed
Receipt of fifty pounds my wife has lent him,
(False woman that she is) for horn-making,
Job journeywork.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You are deceived.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I know.
(At least I think) I am deceived in both.
My money and thy honesty, but the laws
In both shall do me right, or all shall fly for't.
I'll instantly to council.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Hear me first.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: By all means hear her first. Pray grant her that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I dare not look on her, lest I be tempted
To yield unto my shame and my undoing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you not hear your cock, your nansie,
Nanny cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Time was you would not ha' denied me that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nor any thing, if my cock had but stood upon't.
Such was my love, but now,

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But now you're jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Have I not cause?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here's tother fifty pieces, take 'em sir.
They are full weight, and truly told.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Brave wench.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: If you will law, sir, you shall law for something.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope she'll humble him so,
That he shall keep our chamber-door for us,
While we get boys for him. A dainty rogue,
She tempts me strongly now. Would she would call me
About it presently.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That money sir
May serve to countenance you among the gamesters
Within, that blew you up. The lady widow
May think the better of your credit too,
Being so good i'th' house.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll straight amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Council me not sir. All my joys are gone.
I cannot think now what a ducking pond
Can be good for, except to drown me in't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Alas, poor man, I was in this too busy.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Stay, you shall promise me before my husband,
That you will never more attempt my chastity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That bargain's yet to make. Though before him
I may say much, I will not stand to that
For all the wealth he has.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You shall protest
Then, fairly, as you are a gentleman
you never have enjoyed me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I like that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, no, I cannot safely, for in that
I shall surrender up my interest
In's house; and he may warn me out on't. No,
Take heed of that. 'tis not his tother hundred
Shall make me slip that hold.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am lost again.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What a bold thief is this! Pray hear me, sir.
You may remember that I asked you once
What countryman you were.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, when you first cast your good liking on me, and I told you.
sp.l: O'th' isle of wight: and what of that?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you
Call captain Hardyman, their father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You wrong me basely, to say I call him any thing; for he gives me nothing.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You wrong him basely. Look you, can you read.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I had done ill to venture (As I ha' done)
On Salisbury plain else. Ha, what's here
sp.p: That daughter, I sent you order to receive for me an hundred pounds. If you find that your brother the spendthrift Val. Askal, (Zooks that I) be in any want, furnish him according to your own discretion.
sp.l: I am Val. Askal, where's the money? My hundred
Pound, ha' you't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: It seems a sister of yours had it.
Have you a sister?

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: He had a daughter by my mother, but
He placed her out a child, I know not where
Where's that young whore trow? Hannah I think
Her name was. Hang me if 〈◊〉 know directly.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My wives name's Hannah, sir.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I am that sister, brother, but no whore.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. your brags to make men think you lay with her.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You have your hundred pound sir. Look you, husband.
This is my father's letter which you wrote on.
That which you dared the devil and clerks to counterfeit, read your own hand.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Honi soit qui maly pense.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I must admire this woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dost think I did not know thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: No sir, nor would I that you should,
Till I had foiled you in your course,
And had my will to make my husband jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My cock, my cock again, my Nanny cock,
Cock-all my cock-a-hoop, I am overjoyed,
See, see thy father too.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the woman.
To whom I paid your money.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis my daughter —.
My blessing on you. — what are you here too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ask you blessing too. Your hundred pound has bound me to't. Heaven bless you, here's half one still, yes, and the better half, for tother's spent.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: O you're a great good husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would be one. And here's a good rich widow
Now in the house, your countenance may help me,
My sister and my brother both can tell you,
How orderly and civilly I live.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O wag.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis like sir, I shall prove your furtherer.
What is she?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That merchant's sister, and a lady sir.
I would not have him hear.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: Well talk aside then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In that I'm partly satisfied.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I love you sir,
And waited on your wife but as your sp●e,
For fear he might have led her to more folly.

sp.speaker: Mat:
sp.l: But saw you not two such damsels here?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Here are
Some in the house that would not be seen by us.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Because they thought you'd know 'em.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And if that
Old fellow be your brother Strigood, 'tis most strange

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You know not him here do you?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No not I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis my man cash.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Most wonderful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We shall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Pray haste sir, to discovery: I would fain
Once see my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would see a little
The fashions o'the house first.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Pray obscure
Yourselves in that by room there, where you may
See and hear all that passes, nor can any
Pass out o'th' house without your notice.
The gentlemen and I will mix again
With the society, if they please.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Agreed.
Within Strigood. Where are you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Come away Val.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is not that the hellhounds voice?

sp.speaker: Cash
sp.l: Yes, 'tis your brother.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good captain go with us upon discovery.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I'll seat you to see all, and be unseen.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do so good cock. Do so now sir, I'll fetch the priest.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O gentlemen, you have lost such sport, the
Lady
And merchant's wife have been by th' ears.

sp.speaker: Cash
sp.l: Could not
The old knight part 'em?

sp.speaker: Stri
sp.l: He has done his best,
And almost lost his eyes in the adventure
Betwixt the furies' talons ▪

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But are they friends again?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And deep in compliment.
Our school affords no such in act or language.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sister, indeed I am too much your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray madam let me serve you truly truly.
I'll be your servant for a year and a day

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed you wrong yourself, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am your servants servant, and will serve
Under your ladyship's cook to do you service.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed you may not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If I may not be
Accepted for your household servant, let me
Become your charwoman ▪ in any office
From cupboard to (Lose-stool, I can do all
To do your ladyship service.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: This now savours of compliment indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: In sooth, 'tis sooth, forsooth the tale I tell you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Well acted mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You're too obsequious
Good gentle sister.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am short of good.
Gentle I grant I am, for I bite nobody ,
Command me then sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And very well acted Nant.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O you shall pardon me ▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am no Pope, for your sake would I were.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your courtesy o'ercomes me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O not so.
I wish it could forsooth, would it were better for you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Exceeding well acted o'both sides.
Mother and aunt forsooth, Amardla you have done't
Better than the two school-mystresses today
Could do their whatshicomes, their compliments
I think you call 'em. But I ha' lost my mistress
To compliment withal. Mrs. blithe Tripshort
Has outstripped me, Amardla that she has.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where's her wise uncle should ha' looked to her.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: He's crying all about the house for her,
But cannot find her. How shall I have her now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou shalt not have her boy, she's naught.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Then he's
Naught too. You shan't have him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor will, I fear not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Think of the gentleman, mother that outfaced
The Frenchman for me. I would you had a thousand such in France now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: God-a-mercy boy.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Peace, hear a little more.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sir; come away.
I have found a careless curate, that has nothing but a bare coat too loose shall chop't up presently. And give him but a piece, he'll fear no cannon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I am bound to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Whither goes he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No matter, let him go truss perhaps.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I say she is i'th house.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's gone, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's flown out of a window, or chimney-top then.
I'm sure I watched the door with epen eyes
E'er since you entered, as my lady charged me,
Lest her child might slip out to play i th' street.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And I am here you see. He cannot see
He has no more eyes than a sucking pig,
And yet he weeps like a roasted one.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I am abused,
And render me my niece,
You have stolen her for your son.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My son defies her,
As I do you, old whining withered fellow,
That has no moisture in him but for tears.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That is my cue. A young well governed man
Were fitter, madam.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Where have you been servant?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I speak to my lady.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My lady, I think you said.
Are you so stout sir ▪ hah?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I rather think he plays the cunning hypocrite
with his false tears, and packed her hence himself

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My lady minds you not, and I can learn
To give you a broad side too.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, that cannot be, for I have seen
All that went out, or came into the house ▪
Since you. Here came a church man in ere while.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A churchman! then I fear she's closely married unto her woe and mine.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Perhaps to me.
Behind my back you said she would do so.
And before him came in your brother Matchil.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My brother, who her husband?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Yes, with others.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My husband, I think you said what a foul house these washing days make?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no jest now ladies let me tell you,
And sad sir Swithin; pray lend all your ears.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Cash, we are betrayed Cash if we be not nimble.
I smell a fox. High thee up quickly cash,
And hurry down the wenches we'll make bold with
My lady's coach to hurry us away.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But not too fast, go sir, fetch down the wenches.
Thou shameless reprobate. Dost thou hang thy head now?
I'll take a course to hang the rest o'thee.
Your ladyships well met at the new school.
So is your charwoman. Have you profited
By the devil's doctrine here? you weep sin Swithin
For the iniquity of the times.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: You mean
His niece, pray uncle did you meet her,
She's gone away too, after my cousin Joyce,
and the French maid, I think, she is here again.
Amardla, wipe your eyes, and look sir Swithin,
The tother honest gentleman has found her.
And let him take her for his pains for me.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I thank your love. But sir, 'tis your consent
We only seek.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir Swithin, let 'em have it,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the gentleman I would have spoke for:
In birth, in means, in person every way
Deserving her. Take him upon my word.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And madam, since you stick but upon jointure,
Having heard lately well of his husbandry.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Thank a good sister, sir.

sp.speaker: Hard.
